Given the state of the United States economy and the recent comment attributed to the Chairman of the US Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, that the remarkable run of economic growth in his country appears to have its roots in advances in technology, in Australia right now, with the price of fuels as they are and the Australian dollar being in the doldrums, we should be demanding that our Treasurer in particular understand the importance of energy and its cost to the world of the future.

speech.para: Before I address the real nature of this private member's motion before the House today, let me state that the world is being held to ransom by a ruthless cartel of oil producers and processors. We cannot blame them because they control the most widely used source of energy for vehicles and industry. They have a diminishing resource and an increasing demand. They do not even have to market their product. Would such a cartel be interested in developing an alternative fuel for internal combustion engines? The answer is no. Why? Because they would be creating a competitor to their existing product. But here in Australia we are different. Our currently productive oil fields have a life expectancy, based on current rates of extraction, of about four to five years. Known reserves extend that out to between 10 and 15 years. But after that we are thrown onto the list of countries totally dependent for liquid hydrocarbon fuels on imported product. As we approach that date, we cannot expect mercy. We will not get it. Fuel prices we are paying now are only an entree to what we will be paying unless we look for an alternative.

The amazing fact is that there are alternatives. Other forms of energy exist that are both feasible and sustainable. The member for La Trobe outlined just one. The problem is that they are not controlled by the energy cartel and, therefore, they are not promoted. Personally, I have been promoting ethanol as an alternative—an easy step for industry to take because it can be blended with existing fuels and used in existing internal combustion engines. We also have scientists that have developed the technology. The suggestion in the motion today—and I am proud to support it—is a little more radical in that it is encouraging a break from tradition. It is a quantum step forward using a new technology.

It is not that the hydrogen cell is new. I am sure that most of us can remember a science experiment when we were in junior high school where our science teacher passed an electric current through some water with a little acid and we got one gas that was two times the quantity of the other and he used this to tell us that water was H2O and you had two parts of hydrogen to one of oxygen. If he was a particularly brave science teacher, he might have held a lighted taper to the hydrogen and we would have seen that gas that had been produced from water burnt with a hot flame.

That is the secret about what we are debating today and how to harness that energy. The amazing thing about this substance as a fuel is that no carbon is involved in the equation of burning hydrogen: no greenhouse gases are produced by burning hydrogen. The added beauty is that there are no carcinogens—just water. Too simple to believe? Why haven't we been using it, commercially at any rate? Once again, it is about energy. The production of hydrogen by electrolytic processes is an endothermic reaction and it requires the input of energy to liberate the hydrogen. Then there is the burning of the hydrogen, or the generation of electricity using the hydrogen—an exothermic reaction. It is a case of getting the balance right.

There are a couple of variations on this theme. You can have a completely enclosed cell—the sort that our colleague was talking about that was built way back in the 19th century but not developed until the 1960s. It was so successful that the United States used it in rocket technology and space exploration. It is still using it today. As a matter of fact, the United States government has 30 such cells still in use. I believe that the space shuttle that brings astronauts back to earth is currently employing one of these cells. That in itself is an indication of why Australia should be investing money in this sort of technology.

Australian scientists have shown for a long time that we can match it with the world, but they need encouragement. Last week, in a speech I made on legislation that went through this House—I was very happy to speak on it—one of the pieces of information I used was to show that in the past four years investment in technology in this country by private enterprise has dropped by 20 per cent. That is a tragedy. With high fuel prices, with the Australian dollar low and with our oil reserves dwindling, it is an ideal time for our government to show leadership and to encourage industry to invest.

This is a government that has a self-admitted windfall profit from the current fuel taxing regime. I would suggest to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer that they should immediately invest. I can understand the preoccupation with the fiscal surplus, but I have always argued, and will continue to argue, that if some of that surplus is spent in developing new technology or providing infrastructure it is not expenditure but investment and should be regarded as such.

Continuing down the path of time, we know we are going to run out of liquid hydrocarbons, and we know we will have to replace those fuels. They are not simply going to fall off a shelf. The process of replacing them will take time, it will take investment, and it will take finetuning. That is why we need to start today. Tomorrow will be too late. We have to be competitive with the world. We know that. We have to be self-sufficient in energy. Energy is the name of the game. Whoever controls the energy of the world will eventually control the world—I have no doubt about that—because we are such major consumers of energy.

I am very pleased to support this private member's motion. I hope that it leads on to something far more advanced, something far more constructive, by the government. As I indicated in my initial opening comments, it is up to the government to show leadership. Industry is pulling away from investing in new technology, but the amazing thing is that Australians are some of the greatest users of new technology in the world. We sit back and we allow the United States to develop new technology and then we step in and buy it. With an Australian dollar priced at US50c, it is costing us far more than it was 12 months ago. I hate to think what it might be costing us in years to come. I believe that Australia can do it. The member for La Trobe believes that Australia can do it. All we have to do is to convince Australian industry to get out there and do it.

talk.start.para: —It gives me a great deal of pleasure to rise to support this motion of the member for La Trobe. It is a timely debate, following as it does on last week's visit to parliament by eminent scientists to highlight the need for ongoing research in all fields. Australia is well placed with fossil fuels by comparison with many other countries, but the use of these fossil fuels in every case contributes further to destructive greenhouse gases. Australia is well placed with many sites suitable for wind turbines and solar power generation. The northern coast of Western Australia experiences exceptional tidal movement—in the Kimberley region, some 11 metres. The problem to date with renewable energy, however, has been storage.

speech.para: Another problem we as Australians have is finding a solution to the problem of the two per cent renewables target set by the federal government as part of our response to the Kyoto agreements. A solution can now be achieved by conversion to and storage of hydrogen. The conversion of water to hydrogen and oxygen by electrolysis using clean renewable energy is the most effective means of combating increasing world atmospheric pollution. As an energy source for motor vehicles using fuel cell technology, it offers a solution to the looming crisis of maintaining the transportation of people and products with an ever decreasing supply of comparatively dirty fossil fuel.

Professor Peter Newman of the Institute for Sustainability and Technology Policy from Murdoch University states, `In the next decade global oil production will peak, as for each barrel of oil discovered four are now consumed.' As an energy carrier, hydrogen is as easily handled as natural gas. Any gas reticulation system could be utilised to take non-polluting energy to more populous centres. Mr Erhard Schubert, coordinator of General Motors' Global Alternative Propulsion Centre, said that fuel cell power was the only energy source able to satisfy the world's need for a lasting reduction in carbon dioxide emissions despite a steady increase in the number of motor vehicles on the road. He also warned that zero emissions mobility was possible only if large-scale hydrogen production was possible through renewable sources. Quite obviously, there is nothing to be gained by utilising liquid hydrocarbons to split water into hydrogen and oxygen to then use as a supposed clean energy source because we have already created the atmospheric pollution.

I am pleased to report that the Western Australian Department of Transport, in cooperation with Daimler and BHP, are keen to introduce hydrogen fuel cell powered commuter buses. In line with this, the Western Australian government is considering a potential clean renewable energy source that is proposed in Derby, Western Australia. With the capacity of nearly 100 megawatts of output, it would provide ample power for the immediate and future needs of the West Kimberley. The outstanding significance of this project, however, is the opportunity to prove up the total process with a secure supply contract with Western Power.

Further north, along the Kimberley coast, geographic features provide perfect locations for similar installations with a design capacity for 500 megawatt plus. With this clean, renewable electricity and an ample supply of clean fresh water, the potential exists to produce hydrogen to feed into pipeline infrastructure to major population centres. The options for hydrogen use require a great deal of long-term forecasting of economic, environmental and energy constraints and opportunities. The potential exists to share distribution facilities across this nation. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: — Whilst I have great respect for the member for La Trobe, I wish to speak against the motion because the main problem in producing hydrogen is that it takes a very great deal of electrical energy to produce, and there are environmental consequences as a result of greenhouse emissions. If one could produce hydrogen without any adverse environmental effects, I would be supporting the motion. In a few weeks, the governments of the world will convene in The Hague to discuss the implications of the latest findings on global warming and climate change. In a leaked report, the respected UN sponsored Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has warned that the effects of global warming caused by human activities are now starting to have significant effects on the world's weather. Over 70 million people living in low lying areas of Bangladesh and China are at risk of storm surges and flooding. Where will these people go if they are drowned out of their houses? Perhaps they will embark for Australia's somewhat drier shores. In the last two years, we have seen massive flooding and mudslides in Venezuela and Mozambique, devastating hurricanes in the Caribbean and Orissa, India and inextinguishable forest fires in Greece and the western United States. Climate scientists have repeatedly warned that the earth's climate is warming up due to increasing levels of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere, yet the Howard government argues that Australia is a special case and should be allowed to release even larger quantities of pollution. As I have stated before in this House, this government's policies are not based on evidence and the best advice but, rather, on opinion and prejudice together with the pleadings of uninformed special interests.

speech.para: The evidence that the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change has presented is virtually unassailable. I will detail some of the evidence here, since it seems that the government's advisers have not been allowed to present data that does not correspond to official prejudice. Firstly, there is no doubt that carbon dioxide gas present in the atmosphere traps outgoing infra-red radiation and directly heats the atmosphere. This is a measurable effect and has been understood for over 100 years. Secondly, large-scale burning of fossil fuels like coal or oil or natural gas is adding carbon dioxide to the existing concentration in the atmosphere. This concentration can be measured, and the ratio of different isotopes proves that a portion of the increase is coming from the burning of fossil fuels. Thirdly, the overall atmospheric temperature directly affects the intensity and frequency of weather processes such as cyclones and heatwaves. The increasing frequency of these destructive events can be correlated with the measurable increase in atmospheric temperature. The government continues to argue that any measures that may be required to reduce Australia's carbon dioxide emissions would either be too expensive or cause unnecessary disruption to our way of life. With this attitude, it is no wonder that the inhabitants of the small Pacific island nations who are at risk of being washed out of their homes by rising sea levels and devastating hurricanes have no time for Australia's position. I would like to refer members of the government to a recent statement by the British environment minister, Mr Michael Meacher MP. In a column in the Manchester Guardian on 31 October, Mr Meacher said:

quote.para: Climate change is not some trendy intellectual scenario for the distant future. It is with us now.

speech.para: This statement was made in the wake of disastrous storms and floods that killed at least seven people and caused unprecedented damage to railways in the West Country.

While the government may wish to forget about events on the other side of the planet, it still has to face the issue of fuel prices, a topic that is in fact directly linked to the problems created by carbon dioxide emissions. I say this because, as I have previously reported, the fuel consumption figures for Australian vehicles are at the bottom of the list of OECD countries, at 8.9 litres per 100 kilometres. In fact, the thermal efficiency of most Australian vehicles is no more than about 15 per cent. This means that 85 per cent of the energy in the fuel is wasted by these cars and for every dollar a motorist puts into the fuel tank only 15c is actually used to move the vehicle.

While the Prime Minister argues about fuel prices with the premiers and claims that there is nothing he can do, the best answer, which is getting the manufacturers to improve the designs of their engines, is put in the too-hard basket. The low fuel efficiency of our vehicle fleet contributes directly to our increasing greenhouse gas emissions and gives the lie to the government's pleading of Australia as a special case. Put simply, the lower the fuel efficiency, the more fuel a vehicle has to burn and the greater the emission of greenhouse gas. Anybody who lives in our larger cities knows that the volume of traffic is an ever growing problem. People are crying out for a viable alternative to the pollution spewing cars and trucks that jam the streets, yet the only viable alternative, new railways, does not seem to have much federal public funding support. Despite the fact that electric railways are perhaps five times as energy efficient as road transport, the federal government has not provided one single cent for new railway construction. The government's position on greenhouse gases is completely untenable and Australia risks becoming a pariah state.

talk.start.para: (Mr Nehl)—The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

subdebateinfo.title: United Nations: Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women

talk.start.para: —I move:

motion.para: That this House:

(1) Congratulates the countries of Argentina, Austria, Belgium, Benin, Bolivia, Bulgaria, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Croatia, Cuba, Czech Republic, Denmark, Dominican Republic, Ecuador, Finland, France, Germany, Ghana, Greece, Iceland, Indonesia, Italy, Liechtenstein, Luxembourg, Mexico, Namibia, The Netherlands, Norway, Panama, Paraguay, The Philippines, Portugal, Senegal, Slovakia, Slovenia, Spain, Sweden, Thailand, the former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia, Uruguay and Venezuela for being signatories to the Optional Protocol to the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of all forms of Discrimination Against Women (CEDAW);
(2) Recognises the CEDAW as the only woman specific human rights mechanism at the international level;
(3) Recognises that the Optional Protocol to the CEDAW is a major step forward in realising Governments' commitments with regard to women's human rights;

(4) Recognises that the Optional Protocol to the CEDAW creates procedures for the United Nations to promote the enjoyment of human rights to all women and the world-wide elimination of discrimination against women;
(5) Recognises that signatories to the Optional Protocol to the CEDAW reject all forms of injustice and systemic discrimination suffered by women world-wide;
(6) Recognises that the Optional Protocol provides a significant opportunity for women who have suffered from discrimination to seek justice through the United Nations;

(7) Expresses concern at the significantly diminished role Australia is playing in the negotiations of the Optional Protocol to the CEDAW and the low priority given to the Optional Protocol by the Howard Government;
(8) Calls on the Howard Government to take an active role in the negotiation process and to promote a speedy ratification of the Optional Protocol; and
(9) Calls on the Howard Government to have Australia become a signatory to the Optional Protocol to the CEDAW.

speech.para: In moving the motion, I would like to start by saying I welcome the debate on women's rights and make mention of the fact that, like most issues which need proper consideration by this government, this debate has been a long time coming. The issue of women's rights and this government's refusal to sign the optional protocol of the United Nations Convention for the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women is something that will haunt this government and will continue to tarnish Australia's reputation. I am hopeful that opening this debate is the first step for this government towards making an undeniable and firm commitment to rejecting all forms of discrimination against women wherever and whenever they occur. However, I would like to say from the start that the Prime Minister's refusal to allow Australia to become a signatory to the optional protocol is an outright disgrace. During the 13 years that Labor was in power, between 1983 and 1996, Australia took on with vigour the challenge, through the committee system of the UN, to become a leader and to reject injustice and blatant discrimination against women.

Australia was once a leading player in the negotiations and formulation process and worked with the United Nations to form CEDAW. Australia signed CEDAW in 1982, and in 1995 led negotiations to create an optional protocol that would strengthen it. Australia, in its second periodic report to the CEDAW committee, on 31 January 1994, argued strongly for the case for raising the awareness of women's rights both within Australia and worldwide through the United Nations. Australia identified areas of women's rights on which CEDAW should focus. These included the representation of women in public life, policy making and senior executive positions in the government and corporate sectors. Australia argued for the eradication of barriers which prevent equal access for women to these positions in society.

Australia also argued that CEDAW should recognise domestic violence and that that violence against women was a violation of human rights and a form of discrimination against women. Australia argued that CEDAW should focus on eradicating discrimination suffered by disadvantaged groups within a nation—such as indigenous women, migrant women, women of non-English speaking background and women with disabilities. Discrimination and violations of human rights among these groups of women often lead to high infant mortality, low life expectancy, high unemployment, a high incidence of domestic violence and a high incidence of homicide.

It was these kinds of initiatives which led Kofi Annan, on his recent visit to Australia, to state that Australia was a model nation of the United Nations. The editorial of the Melbourne Age on Monday, 9 October stated many of the injustices and discrimination suffered by women which were included in a recent UN report. According to the Age, this report stated such shocking statistics as four million girls and women, mainly on the Asian continent, being sold into prostitution or slavery each year, and reported injustices such as in the Middle East, where up to 5,000 women are killed every year in what they call `honour killings'. If we are a model nation of the UN, let us lead from the front and not from behind. Let us continue this leadership role and show, both to other countries in our region and to other members of the UN, that we do care. Being a model nation should mean that we believe discrimination against women in all its forms should be eliminated, even if much of this discrimination and disadvantage to women does not occur on our shores. Australia should condemn the existence of discrimination against women and support avenues such as this optional protocol, which will help to eradicate it.

This government has made no secret of the fact that it is embarrassed and angered by criticism from the United Nations Human Rights Committee over the government's decision not to overturn mandatory sentencing legislation in the Northern Territory. Even members of the government's own backbench agree that mandatory sentencing in the Northern Territory should be overturned, but still this government, in its characteristically stubborn way, has refused to overturn this piece of legislation. Instead this government has pushed for what it calls `reform' of the United Nations committee system.

No-one can deny Australia's right as a member of the United Nations to suggest reform of the committee system. However, I want to talk about the manner in which this government has gone about arguing for reform. Reforms need to be achieved by firm, consistent diplomacy, not through what we have seen so far from this government, which is non-cooperation with the UN and self-assessment of domestic policies. The international and universal rights of women should not be used as a political pawn by the Howard government to defend its own policies that are criticised by the UN. It may be true that countries like Australia are judged more harshly than some others, partly because higher standards are expected from such a well developed and democratic country as Australia. However, this is the standard we have set for ourselves through the active role previous Australian governments have played in the UN. The Australian government is expected, both by the electorate and by the international community, to live up to this standard. By refusing to sign the optional protocol and by witnessing the diminished role the Howard government is playing in the negotiation process, it is quite clear that we are not living up to this standard. The optional protocol is an avenue for creating international law. It provides an opportunity for women to make a complaint to the United Nations if the domestic mechanisms of law have been exhausted or, in many cases, do not exist in their countries.

At the International Women's Conference in Beijing in 1995, the leaders of the world's nations confirmed that women's rights are human rights. They are one and the same. They are universal. This confirmed that women's rights are not confined to a particular nation, religion or culture. The conference ensured that women's rights are recognised as worldwide universal human rights. Declaring this also means that to deny women their rights is a breach of human rights. At the Beijing conference, Australia, with its representatives from the former Keating government, called for a speedy entry into force of the optional protocol and also called on members of the United Nations to consider ratifying the optional protocol as quickly as possible. This optional protocol will protect rights enshrined in CEDAW. These rights cover such issues as health, education, marriage, pregnancy, family relations, human rights, equity before the law, and the right to participate equally, with equal rights and status, in all areas of public and civil rights.

The terms of the optional protocol are broad. It acknowledges women's rights—again I repeat this—as human rights. It encourages all governments to take active and continuing steps to advance women's status and women's rights, economically, politically, socially and culturally. The point should also be made that the optional protocol does not create new rights for women but only includes the rights that are already enshrined in the CEDAW proposal to which Australia was a signatory in 1982. That was 18 years ago. It is a sad reflection of this government's arrogance and backward thinking logic that Australia will not now be a signatory of the optional protocol.

The Prime Minister has argued that a developed, democratic country like Australia already adequately protects human rights and the rights of women through such things as antidiscrimination and equal opportunity legislation. If this is the case, Prime Minister, let us not close our doors to the international community. Let us proudly open them, sign and ratify the optional protocol and make a statement which says to the Asia-Pacific region, to the United Nations and to the international community that we are Australia, we reject all forms of discrimination against women wherever they occur and we believe women should have the right to fight gross injustice and violations of human rights through the avenues of the United Nations. This country has made much progress in antidiscrimination and equal opportunity legislation, but I believe we must now show other nations that we are there and show them examples so that they can follow our lead.

We must take a leading role in the optional protocol development. There is so much for Australia to gain by signing the optional protocol to CEDAW. The optional protocol will show to our regional neighbours that Australia recognises that women's rights need to be protected and that Australia is a country which believes women should have the right to take their complaints to the UN if they feel their human rights are being breached. There is nothing for Australia to gain by being stubborn, arrogant and complacent and by not signing this protocol. Time is running out for this government to sign the optional protocol, which will come into effect on 22 December 2000. To date, the optional protocol has 62 signatories, and 11 of these countries have ratified it. If this country continues to flounder about arguing the case for reform of the UN committee system and continues to use the argument of national sovereignty against UN criticism of domestic policies, Australia will miss the boat.

In conclusion, I say: Prime Minister, let us not the miss the boat on women's rights. Australia has been a leader on women's rights. If you look at issues such as women's suffrage, equal employment opportunity, antidiscrimination and maternity leave for Australian women, Australia has always been a pioneer and has played a leading part. Women's rights are human rights. They need to be protected both within Australia and around the world. Women should not be denied the right to take their complaints to the United Nations for international consideration. Australia's reputation needs to remain as a leader rather than as an objector on the issue of human rights. Prime Minister, advance Australia forward through CEDAW. Don't drop the ball on all the remarkable progress Australia has achieved in the past on women's issues. Women have come so far forward during the 20th century. Let us not have Australia's reputation go down. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve my right to speak.

—I rise today to speak to the motion moved by the member for Prospect, and I take great delight in speaking on this motion because I am utterly opposed to the implied criticism of this government's position in relation to the optional protocol to the UN Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women. Once again we see the Labor opposition downplaying Australia's record in the eyes of the world. Never, ever do we hear a positive move for the Australian people to associate with. All we ever hear is negativity, doom and gloom, when we, the citizens of Australia, are proud of our country's reputation and will defend it against all those who try to make us seem inferior.

speech.para: Let us look at the reasons for the optional protocol. The first aim is to improve on and add to existing enforcement mechanisms for women's human rights. Australian woman, unlike those of many Third World countries, are not left unprotected. For that we can thank the women of our country who went before us, along with the rest of Australian society. There is no need for additional enforcement mechanisms in Australia. We are well provided for by our sex discrimination legislation, and many avenues for appeal exist in the judicial system and through our administrative process under the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commissioner—a total separate identity away from political barriers and influence. Of course, Australian woman still have the protection of the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women itself. In the event that the will of the people changes in respect of any cultural norm relating to the specific rights of women, there is the well-known and oft-trodden path to legislative change as determined by Australia and its people.

The second aim is to improve states' and individuals' understanding of CEDAW. Before the time of the original introduction of the Sex Discrimination Act there was, and there still is, wide debate of the issues which will, I am sure, continue well after we have gone. Along with ongoing gender equity programs in schools and other training institutes, relevant information is available in the media, from all government agencies and from women's organisations both state and federal. I do not believe that signing the optional protocol would have any benefit, and it may in fact create weaknesses and discrepancies in our current system.

The third aim is to stimulate states to take steps to implement CEDAW. As outlined above, Australia has already met the requirements of most articles under the Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women. In fact, our current legislation is constantly under review by all levels of government and human rights groups to determine loopholes or weaknesses. The Howard government has already identified a need to amend the Sex Discrimination Act to protect the rights of pregnant and breast-feeding women—something the previous government failed to do.

The fourth aim is to stimulate changes in discriminatory laws and practices. As outlined earlier, there is stimulation enough to continually monitor any discriminatory impact on our current legislation and practices. Our Australian women are empowered and totally free to raise these issues in every forum possible, with considerable influence and with good positive results. In fact, our Country Women's Association branches throughout Australia regularly meet to discuss and debate any issue of concern to women in rural and regional areas. And, as I am sure everyone in this chamber can testify, women have not been slow to let their elected representatives know their feelings.

The fifth aim is to enhance existing mechanisms for the implementation of human rights within the United Nations system. Australia's strong human rights record is widely acknowledged around the world, including by the United Nations. We have a strong record of support and protection of women's rights. Australia has a world-class regime of legislation and institutional mechanisms to protect women against discrimination. The government in its review of the United Nations treaty system has found substantial weaknesses to which we certainly do not want to become a party. Australian standards are high in comparison to many other countries.

The sixth aim is to create greater public awareness of human rights standards relating to discrimination against women. Australia has again played a leading role in supporting women's human rights in the work of the United Nations. This government supports the Beijing platform for action and will actively be implementing the Beijing Plus Five outcomes document. I acquaint the House that it was the United Nations Division for the Advancement of Women that presented Beijing Plus Five, which was a special session of the General Assembly entitled `Women 2000: gender equality, development and peace for the 21st century', held from 5 to 9 June 2000 at the United Nations headquarters in New York. The Beijing declaration and platform for action were adopted at the Fourth World Conference of Women from 4 to 15 September 1995 by representatives from 189 countries. I know a number of women from my own electorate who attended that meeting.

The platform reflects a new international commitment to the goals of equality, development and peace for all women everywhere. It then builds on the commitments made during the United Nations Decade for Women from 1976 to 1985, including at the Nairobi conference, and continues on related commitments made in the cycle of United Nations global conferences held in the 1990s. The platform identifies the following 12 critical areas of concern for women's advancement and empowerment: poverty, education and training, health, violence, armed conflict, economy, decision making, institutional mechanisms, human rights, media, environment and the girl child. The platform for action defined strategic objectives and spelt out the actions needed to be taken by governments, the international community, non-government organisations and the private sector. Five years after Beijing, the special session in June 2000 provided an opportunity for all concerned to share and compare experiences, to renew old commitments, to make new ones and to examine obstacles encountered, as well as good practices in implementing the platform for action.

Let us examine the plight of Australian women in relation to these 12 critical areas of concern, being for women's advancement and empowerment. Employment is one of the ways to escape the net of poverty. It is a fact that more women are in paid employment now than ever before—68.5 per cent of working age women, aged 15 to 64, were in the paid labour force in September 2000, second only to our record high in August this year of 66.2 per cent. I remind the member for Prospect that is more than under any other previous government. Female employment grew by 410,000, more than 11 per cent, between March 1996 and September 2000. No, they were not all part-time, casual or seasonal jobs. In fact, the split was roughly fifty-fifty. Of the extra 410,000 jobs, 210,200 were full-time and 202,300 were part-time jobs. Unemployment in September 2000 was at an equal record six per cent for the second time this year—the first time was July 2000. This was the lowest rate in decades for women and was considerably lower than when it was eight per cent in March 1996, after 13 years of Labor.

However, still not satisfied with its efforts, this government then focused on women wanting to return to the work force after an absence: for example, to have and to care for children—another choice this government supports through financial incentives. We recognise that many women choose to take a break from the work force and may have initial difficulty in finding their way back. Hence the federal government has provided $24 million for its return to work program. This will assist particularly women re-entering the work force, after a break of two years or more as parents or carers, by helping them identify their advantages and also opportunities to train in areas of interest.

Speaking of education, women now make up 58 per cent of students commencing undergraduate degrees at university. The most heartening figure for me, someone who was required to leave school at 15 to assist the family budget, is the proportion of women in postgraduate studies. This has risen from 43.5 per cent in 1996 to 52.7 per cent in 1999, which shows just how successful our strategies have been in redressing the previous imbalance. The figure is always increasing under this federal government's guidance—through the New Apprenticeships program. Training and employment are not enough to ensure empowerment, although they certainly go a long way to help.

Domestic violence has systematically been used to keep women powerless. In some countries that has been one of the cultural norms. In Australia we recognise that violence against women is unacceptable—in all its forms. To highlight this government's commitment to finding better ways of preventing domestic violence, we have spent $50 million on such a program. Education programs in schools are already teaching that this kind of behaviour is not the norm and is not acceptable. Nowhere have I heard or seen the opposition applaud our stance on greater financial support for child care or for the flexibility that it provides.

I have demonstrated some of the practical ways in which this government has addressed the possibility of gender inequality inherent in our institutions. Our women are professional in their workplaces and are positive in their attitudes. In fact, there is now a growing percentage of women on boards as directors, both in the government and non-government sectors. Women are logical and most of these women are now in the work force, as I have said. I serve this country with great pride, pride in knowing that we stand for all things good, including the right to vote without the use of guns and the right to speak freely, to think freely and to make objection if treated unfairly. We live in a democratic society because our forebears, both men and women, fought so hard for those rights. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak in support of the motion by the member for Prospect. I am pleased to do so because the member for Prospect has considerable experience of the world and has a mature sense of judgment. It is a pity that the member for Gilmore is not like Janice Crosio and the next woman I am going to speak about, Dame Beryl Beaurepaire. This is about all women in Australia and the world. Can't you stand up for all women?

speech.para: Dame Beryl Beaurepaire, the very model of a liberal, one of the leaders of the delegation that signed the convention in Copenhagen in 1980, shares the member for Prospect's concerns that this government is letting down the world's women. This government does not share the maturity of the member for Prospect and of Dame Beryl. The government has acted out of immaturity because the UN convention machinery has been critical on the issue of the rights of Australia's Aboriginal people. We can expect that because higher standards are expected of our liberal and enlightened society. To pick up the bat and ball and refuse to play anymore is plainly childish and immature. Other nations look to Australia, as Australia's Sex Discrimination Commissioner, Susan Halliday, points out. It is not just about us: women in the Asia-Pacific region depend on a bit of leadership from Australia.

The government's aim—to knock the UN until it smartens itself up—has been criticised by the Australian Council for Overseas Aid, because it gives comfort to those who commit human rights abuses. It flies in the face of what the optional protocol is all about. Australia had a big hand in this. The Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women was signed by a Liberal government. This Liberal government must finish its work in this important area of human rights. There are three billion women in the world and 70 per cent of them are poor. Women in some countries are burnt or disfigured because of dowry demands. They are murdered when they are judged to have brought dishonour on their families for as little a crime as being out after sunset. They are subjected to circumcision practices for no good reason other than narrow cultural beliefs about denying women their sexuality. They are subjected to genital mutilation to ensure their chastity until marriage, again as a tradition without religious basis, and virgins are purchased to bring good fortune to a business deal, a superstition leading to exploitation.

Each year about four million women and girls are sold into sexual slavery. It is an export market which appears to be growing. Female babies are made to disappear at birth because they are less valued than male children. They are aborted, murdered, or are starved and neglected until they die because they are females. Widow burning is still practised. Women are denied education in some cultures, are denied contraception and are forced to live in ignorant poverty with large families and inadequate or no maternity facilities. As Joan Sheldon, the former Queensland Liberal Party head and current shadow minister for industrial relations, said on the ABC:

quote.para: It sends particular messages, particularly to countries overseas where in some of those countries women are terribly discriminated against, they have no rights whatsoever. So it is important that the powerful and democratic nations of the world show by at least signing these sorts of protocols that they think this sort of discrimination should be eliminated.

speech.para: Joan Sheldon, a Liberal state member, is one of millions of women in Australia who are greatly concerned about the government's actions. The feeling of these women was put clearly by Dr Jocelynne Scutt, Tasmania's Anti-Discrimination Commissioner, in the Sunday Age of 3 September 2000:

quote.para: In the 1980s, Australian women coaxed, cajoled, prompted and persuaded successive Australian governments to make significant contributions to the international community's debates and achievements on women's rights.
The women who led this push were strong, wise, persistent.
Most of them are still around, and those who aren't have left behind a legacy that's not forgotten.
Of one thing John Howard and his government can be sure. These bold, brave women are on hand for the new millennium. And there are thousands—no millions—more around now.
Women don't forget our struggles so easily.

speech.para: I heartily agree. Women in Australia have come a long way, but we still have a long way to go. Women will remember the actions of this government at the next election and the comments of the member for Gilmore, who I believe is in a marginal Liberal seat, and there are a lot of women voters there. At the next election, the women of Australia will elect a decent government, a Beazley Labor government. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak on the motion moved by the member for Prospect. I have a great deal of regard for the member for Prospect. I have worked on quite a number of matters with her in the parliamentary processes. I also share the concerns that she has raised about women worldwide—uneducated, abused, degraded, prostituted against their will and, in many other countries, enslaved. I noted the comments of the member for Fowler about maturity and messages, but I will get to that shortly. While it is absolutely appropriate that the member for Prospect raise the very real concerns about the situation that many women worldwide face, that is not reflected in a knee-jerk reaction to the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women and the ramifications in Australia, and I would like to go through those now.

speech.para: I am a member of the Joint Standing Committee on Treaties, so I have a very keen appreciation of and interest in how government looks at international treaties. The reality is that we have moved a long way in the last few years in Australia. I think most Australians are very concerned and interested in what parliaments do about international treaties, protocols, conventions and the like. They want to be involved first of all in public inquiries and then in having a say, and that is right and proper. The parliament is for the people. If they wish to be included, they should be, and we have ensured that they are. I think we should also respect their view of international treaties.

Concerning the domestic progress in human rights, there is a disjointed view that in some way CEDAW is going to change the situation in Australia. The United Nations treaty system is, at best, flawed. There are any number of examples of that. I recall recently the furore in United Nations committees over mandatory sentencing in Australia. In this address, I do not care to canvass the rights and wrongs of mandatory sentencing but simply point out that that was a state decision. The United Nations Committee on the Elimination of All Forms of Racial Discrimination, CERD, which attacked Australia on these matters, was made up of China, Cuba, Egypt and Guinea, described by the international human rights watchdog, Freedom House, as countries that are not free. Two other members of that committee—Pakistan and Russia—are described as only partly free.

The reality is that UN committees do not reflect the view in Australia that Australians have of a democratic system. We are right to condemn worldwide the many perpetrators of abuses against humanity, whether they be against women or other powerless individuals. In many cases, the victims are unable to elicit actions against those perpetrators. There is no doubt, as the member for Prospect has said, that that is absolutely deplorable. The UN committees have to get a result and, unfortunately, they look for soft targets. They look to member nations of the United Nations such as Australia.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—Order! The time allotted for private members business has expired. The debate is adjourned and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting. The honourable member for Dawson will have leave to continue speaking when the debate is resumed.

motion.para: That grievances be noted.

talk.start.para: —Before I commence my speech, I have sought leave from the minister at the table, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, to table a letter to the Director of Public Prosecutions and its attachment. I seek leave to table the document and have it incorporated in Hansard.
(Mr Jenkins)—Is there any objection to leave being granted? There being no objection, leave is granted for the tabling of the document.

—Despite the public's faith in politicians having been damaged recently—again by claims of extravagant allowances, rorts, improprieties and cover-ups—the truth, which is rarely portrayed by a media hungry for scandal and disgrace, is that most of our politicians, from all sides of politics, are hardworking, honest public servants. They do not abuse the privileges which come with their position, nor do they set out to improperly profit from their positions. It is the exception, not the norm, when a politician is identified as a blatant abuser of parliamentary allowances or entitlements. Yet it does happen.

speech.para: Rarely, but sometimes, a politician is identified as being corrupt, self-serving or grotesquely greedy. Not stupid or foolish or negligent or incompetent—adjectives aptly describing Reith, the Prime Minister's fallen star—but occasionally a politician is criminally, fraudulently and unjustifiably greedy. And when this is alleged, justice demands that this person be brought to answer before a court of law, just as we would expect any other citizen charged with a crime would be. There is a perception in the community that, while the Howard government has zero tolerance for welfare recipients who fill in their forms incorrectly and for workers who misuse company entitlements, at the same time politicians are not called to account for the criminal misuse of parliamentary entitlements, defrauding the Commonwealth and defrauding the taxpayer.

The decision to allow former Senator Mal Colston to avoid facing his day in court, however conscientiously made at the time, has become a major contributor to this perception and must be reviewed. The legacy of the last two years of Mal Colston's political career is a blight on the Australian political landscape. He was a man out to get all he could from the system, a man who turned political office into a family money-spinning business and who left politics under a cloud of anger, vitriol and disrepute, a man whose first action on leaving parliament was to write to the Remuneration Tribunal to ask for a free lunch. It was not enough that he and his wife had gold pass travel for the rest of their lives; when they were on a train, the cost of their trip covered by the taxpayer, they wanted a free lunch, too—and dinner and breakfast—at the taxpayer's expense, of course.

The Mal Colston travel rorts affair embroiled the Prime Minister in allegations of political double standards and vote buying, the Senate in allegations of contempt and political interference and the Australian political system in perceptions of snouts in the trough. When Mal Colston's final Senate term expired, he had been charged and indicted with 28 counts of fraud under section 29D of the Crimes Act 1914 of the Commonwealth. Each count carried with it a maximum jail term of 10 years. The charges were laid after more than seven months of allegations, scandals, cover-ups, lies, claims and counterclaims. The charges against Colston related to 44 occasions from 1990 to 1996 where it was alleged that he had claimed up to $300 travel allowance a night for overnight stays in Canberra, Melbourne and Sydney when, in fact, he was at his home base in Brisbane; and they related to allegations that he, breaching government directives, gave his frequent flier points to his two sons for around the world trips. It might be arguable as to whether the latter matter constitutes an offence—the issue of who is the owner of frequent flier points, and the entitlement of the government to give binding directions on that issue, has yet to be authoritatively determined—but the other allegations, if true, are simple examples of corruption.

Colston has always claimed his innocence. At law he is entitled to that presumption. But he has never produced any evidence that is consistent with that claim, apart from a letter from a former staff member claiming that she was responsible for false travel allowance claims—a letter which she later revealed was a complete fabrication on the part of Colston. Seen in that light, it was also a contempt of parliament and an attempt to cover up a crime. Despite having many opportunities, Colston has never—not to this parliament when he was a member, not to the court during his committal hearing and not to the media to whom he has given interviews—said anything to suggest that he is anything other than what he was charged as: a fraudster who knowingly and wilfully exploited his position to benefit illegitimately at the expense of the Australian people.

Today, more than three years after he was charged with fraud, he has still not had to face trial. Unless the DPP or the Attorney-General change their minds, he never will. On 5 July 1999, the Director of Public Prosecutions decided not to proceed with his prosecution on the grounds that Colston was not fit to stand trial and that there was no likelihood that he would become fit to stand trial. The decision was made on the basis of independent medical reports, which the Attorney will not release to the public, and medical reports submitted to the DPP by Colston's lawyers. It is now apparent that the DPP's decision to discontinue was based on a mistake of fact.

There is no denying that Colston has cancer. By his own account, he has a very rare form of pancreatic cancer on which very little research has been done and about which very little is known. But by his doctor's 1998 and 1999 accounts, he should be well and truly dead and buried. But he is not. In fact, it appears that he has been surprisingly well and is mentally and physically active. He was not supposed to see the end of 1998, but he is set to see out the first year of the new millennium. Colston lives at home with his family in Chapel Hill, Brisbane, and it is reported that he is building a pool in his front yard. He has been seen in the audience of The New Price is Right and has also been seen dining out, shopping and visiting Canberra. Media reports tell us that he spends most of his time at home, reading the papers and watching TV, in the company of his family—from all accounts, a lifestyle that many hardworking Australians aspire to.

And he is far from being a mental couch potato. He is capable of writing letters to the Senate in response to speeches made by Senator Ray. He is capable of writing letters to the editor of the Courier-Mail warning against the reintroduction of television licences. He is capable of giving interviews to the Australian claiming that he wished he could have had his day in court so that he could have cleared his name. He is capable of travelling to Canberra to thank the staff of the Senate travel department for all their help over the years—the irony of it! He did not write or phone to thank them; no, he travelled here at taxpayer's expense. And he is capable of sitting in the audience of a television program aptly named The New Price is Right.

If Mal Colston is capable of all these things, then he is capable of standing trial for serious and multiple fraud against the Commonwealth. If he is found guilty of the charges, his illness would be an important mitigating factor in sentencing. However, it should not be a barrier to justice being done. The interests of justice require that Colston be made to answer the charges against him. If, as he continues to maintain to all those who will listen, he is in fact innocent, he should be given the chance that he claims he seeks to have his name cleared.

The Australian government, correctly, has felt no compunction about exploring the possibility of seeking a review of Spanish court decisions not to prosecute, decisions apparently made on the basis of mistakes of fact regarding Skase's health status. The Australian Director of Public Prosecutions has not dropped the charges against Skase. This correctly reflects the sentiment of the Australian community that people charged with such matters should not be allowed to get away with evading the courts on what appear to be spurious health grounds.

The Commonwealth's prosecution policy allows the Director of Public Prosecutions to reverse a decision not to proceed to trial in circumstances where the decision was affected by a mistake of fact, and it is in the interests of justice that the decision be reversed. I have today written to the Director of Public Prosecutions, Mr Damian Bugg QC, enclosing a detailed submission as to why the Colston case should, consistent with the prosecution policy of the Commonwealth, be recommenced. That is the document that was tabled at the commencement of this grievance debate. I commend to this House and to the government the opportunity to reflect on this matter. It is one which has done the Australian community a disservice in terms of the perception it has given the members of the public of the work of parliamentarians, and it is an issue which I believe needs to be revisited by the Director of Public Prosecutions.

talk.start.para: (Mr Jenkins)—Order! Before I call the honourable member for Blair, at the outset, the honourable member for Denison asked for certain documents to be tabled and incorporated. The incorporation in Hansard will depend on whether they are inside or outside the guidelines set by the Presiding Officers.

—In question time today the Prime Minister tabled a letter that he has forwarded to the Premier of Queensland, Mr Peter Beattie. In that letter he covered the issues surrounding allegations of electoral fraud reported by the Courier-Mail. In the letter from the Prime Minister to the Premier of Queensland, Mr Peter Beattie, the Prime Minister finished up by stating:

quote.para: If the government of Queensland is unable or unwilling to agree to the course of action outlined—

speech.para: that is, that these allegations reported in the Courier-Mail be forwarded to the Shepherdson inquiry and be investigated by the Shepherdson inquiry—

quote.para: then the Commonwealth government will be obliged to consider its own powers in relation to conducting an inquiry into these allegations.

speech.para: Those allegations that have been put forward by the Courier-Mail are very serious and they certainly warrant investigation by the Shepherdson inquiry, as proposed by the Prime Minister. I certainly would urge the Premier of Queensland to respond to that compelling evidence and to have the allegations investigated by the Shepherdson inquiry. If the comments made by the source quoted by the Courier-Mail are indeed true, then a smear is being cast not only over that one election in 1987, which involved the division of Fisher, but also all those many elections run in Queensland from 1987 to the current day. It is a horrifying prospect. In that period there were something like 15 state by-elections, three Commonwealth by-elections and four state elections. There were Commonwealth elections in that period as well. That should be a serious concern for all members.

In my earlier contribution today I spoke of other allegations that have come to my notice, and these concern the division of Dickson, which was subject to a by-election in 1993. The Liberal Party candidate there was Dr Bruce Flegg and the Labor Party candidate was again Mr Michael Lavarch. That was 7½ years ago. That by-election campaign occurred as a result of the death of a candidate during the earlier federal election campaign. I have spoken to Dr Bruce Flegg about what occurred during that campaign and he reiterates almost exactly the kinds of circumstances that occurred in 1987. The things reported in the Courier-Mail and attributed to that Labor insider could be referred to again in relation to what Dr Bruce Flegg observed during the 1993 campaign—because they were at it again. On that occasion we had paid union officials moving through the electorate, carrying the electoral rolls and going from door to door checking the enrolment of people. This was conducted week in and week out. It was an ongoing solid campaign. Dr Flegg said to me that it was so comprehensive it appeared from their perspective that it covered every elector in the whole of the division of Dickson.

At that time Dickson covered much of the area that is Blair today. While Dickson today is in the northern suburbs of Brisbane, communities such as Rosewood in my very own electorate were then part of Dickson. To have those people doorknocking around Rosewood with an electoral roll is an ominous sign for democracy in this country and certainly for any claim that the Labor Party might endeavour to put that it is free from corruption or allegations of corruption as published in the Courier-Mail on the weekend. But there they were in 1993: union officials going from door to door in the seat of Dickson checking people's enrolments, just as the Labor insider reported it in the Courier-Mail. On the day of the election, as it was noted in 1987, the Labor Party cars appeared and officers started going around those country areas. They were seen in Rosewood. These cars carried groups of people who leapt out of the car at one polling booth, went inside, voted, leapt back into the car and went to another polling booth and were seen to vote there as well. This is the allegation from 1987 as portrayed by the Labor insider quoted in the Courier-Mail, and here is the allegation again with respect to 1993. In that election the seat of Dickson was won by Mr Lavarch by 0.2 per cent—a couple of hundred votes. According to the Labor insider, there would have been no problem for that number of votes to have been cast in this corrupt, questionable and criminal way. So it was occurring across that electorate in 1993 in much the same area that would have been covered by Fisher in 1987, and it is the same candidate—Mr Michael Lavarch.

This is something that has to be rooted out. It has to be tracked down, and every single person who was involved in these exercises—the people who were noted going from door to door by Bruce Flegg and his supporters—have to come forward and account for themselves. The people who were in those cars, moving from polling booth to polling booth and casting their votes, have to explain what they were doing there. Was it legitimate? As far as we can see, if we follow the Courier-Mail and its sources, a very serious question has been raised.

As the Labor Party foot soldier—the `insider' as he was called by the Courier-Mail—said, `If eight workers each came up with 45 names in Fisher, as it was in 1987, it could have been enough to rort the election. According to the reporter in the Courier-Mail, `Since our first conversation, the insider said that he cannot be certain Lavarch would have won the seat unaided.' If that were the case in 1987, it certainly would have been the case in 1993. And yet exactly the same thing is happening all over again.

This is something that should send a shiver down the spine of all Queenslanders. I do hope that Mr Beattie responds to the comments by the Prime Minister and enables a very early resolution of these questions. Were the people in those cars acting improperly? Were the people who went door to door gathering those names acting as a precursor to some kind of electoral rort? We need to know that because, when next an election is held in Queensland, people are entitled to have their vote count and not to have someone come in over the top with some orchestrated campaign to steal the election. This is the kind of thing that is alleged in places like Peru. We send observers to watch elections in places like South Africa and Zimbabwe—to observe that this does not happen—and yet these allegations are occurring right here in our midst.

The Prime Minister is entirely correct to say that, if the Queensland government will not act, then it is important that the federal parliament act. Questions have been raised not just about Queensland members but also about federal members. Mr Michael Lavarch was the federal Attorney-General. I cannot imagine a more terrible allegation. I am sure that Mr Lavarch, who has maintained his innocence, is as horrified about the whole process as I am. From the perspective of Queensland, it is a shame that these things have occurred. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Since 1989 Tasmania has been in receipt of a wheat freight subsidy. The subsidy was introduced by the then Labor government. This subsidy provides support for the pork industry, the stockfeed industry, chicken growers and baking industries. These industries are vital to Tasmania because they directly and indirectly impact on around 1,600 Tasmanian jobs. That might not mean a lot in metropolitan Sydney, but it means an awful lot in rural Tasmania. In 1994 the Labor government extended the funding for a further five years at a rate of $2.7 million per year. Funding was also provided for the upgrade of handling and storage capacity on a dollar-for-dollar arrangement with the state government. The industry believed that it would have security until 1999, which was a pretty reasonable position for it to take—after all, it was the subject of an agreement between state and Commonwealth governments.

speech.para: Discussions had taken place with the Tasmanian Department of Primary Industry and the Tasmanian Grain Elevators Board to work through the issues of the scheme. Then then minister, Mr Anderson, signed up to further improve handling and storage facilities. One can assume that all of these negotiations took place in good faith, but in August 1996 the Treasurer simply ignored that five-year agreement—he ignored the negotiations of his colleagues and slashed the level of funding. Funding for the program was reduced to $1.2 million. The cut-off date for the scheme of June 1999 was looming. There was no provision made for the extension of the scheme in the 1998-99 budget. The budget papers stated that the scheme was to be terminated as a contribution to the government's fiscal target. The Treasurer, Mr Costello, ignored the negative economic consequences for Tasmania of the ending of the scheme, clearly indicating his government's lack of regard for Tasmanian jobs and industries.

During the last federal election, the federal government made only vague commitments to continue with the scheme. It was obvious that it intended to walk away from it. The industry's response was predictable—they fought for the survival of their industries and for the government to either publicly commit to the future of the scheme or to publicly abandon it. The government dealt with the self-induced crisis by committing to the scheme. Suddenly claims emanated from ministers' offices that there had never been an intention to scrap the scheme. I imagine we were supposed to believe it was just carelessly overlooked.

Once through the election, the federal government planned yet another assault on the scheme. In a media statement on 19 February last year, the then agriculture minister, Mr Vaile, stated that the Wheat Freight Subsidy Scheme would continue for only a 12-month period from July 1999. He said that the scheme would continue only until the government's new tax package was operating. It is clear to everyone, including the National Party and Liberal Party members in regional seats, that the new tax system has been an absolute disaster for the bush. The cost of doing business and the cost of living in regional Australia is rapidly escalating, not declining. Business cost structures are going up, not down.

Let us look at petrol and diesel prices as an example. Petrol costs are well over one dollar in most areas in Tasmania. Diesel prices on Flinders Island have been at more than $1.20 per litre. It obviously became clear to the government that the tax package, rather than replacing the benefits flowing from the scheme to Tasmanian businesses, would only make things worse. So the Vaile plan to end the scheme was replaced with a review. However, there is little doubt the Howard government will abandon this scheme if it gets half a chance. I fear the government will look to this much delayed review of the scheme for that chance.

The industries that rely on this important scheme, and the Labor Party, were rightly concerned that the review would be designed by the federal Treasury with a simple financial outcome in mind rather than good industry policy. We still do not know what form that review will take. We do not even know when it will be. The review was due to commence in August. We are now into the second week of November, and there are still no details of the terms of reference. We still do not have any indication of a timetable for the review, and we do not know who will conduct it. We do not know what opportunity there will be for those directly affected industries and other interested parties to have proper input into the review process. It is vital that the chicken industry, the stockfeed industry, the baking industry and the pork industry be given an opportunity to have input into the process. I understand that officers of the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry should oversee this review, but the ever lurking figures of Treasury officials will probably never be far behind.

The review should, if focused on the interests of Tasmania, have regard for the following issues—and please, Minister, pay attention. Proper account must be taken of the impact of the scheme on our economy and those directly affected industries. Grain handling infrastructure must be properly considered. There should be a review of the roles of both the state and federal governments and any impact of any changes to the Bass Strait transport infrastructure. And there must be a look at changing the funding from a financial to a calendar year basis. What we need now are two things: an assurance that the budget papers will include funding for the scheme to give some level of security for the industry, which does have to renegotiate its shipping contracts; also, some information is needed regarding the process of review.

As the government commences work on the 2001-02 budget, it does so in an increasingly uncertain economic climate. There continues to be downward pressure on the Australian dollar and that means an increasing upward pressure on interest rates. There is now clear evidence that the GST is hurting businesses badly, and things can only get worse. The Morgan and Banks poll shows that nearly 95 per cent of businesses have found that the GST has hurt their profits. Petrol prices are basically out of control, and the government's response is simple: `It's not our fault'. With all these economic negatives running against the government, I am concerned that the Treasurer, Mr Costello, will feel the need to pander to the money market in this budget. That is bad news for this important scheme in Tasmania.

If the Howard government, under pressure from the Treasurer, terminates the Tasmanian Wheat Freight Subsidy Scheme, a number of things will certainly happen. Bulk wheat shipments to Tasmania will stop and any wheat imported to the state will be shipped in via containers. It will become cheaper to import processed products rather than to import wheat and process it in the state. So we can say goodbye to our value adding. The federal government, by that one action, would transfer hundreds of jobs in bulk grain storage, handling and transport, in animal feed milling and flour milling and in poultry and pigmeat, egg production, abattoirs and other process activities from Tasmania to the mainland. There will be a reduced demand for Tasmanian grains as processors move from Tasmania, resulting in fewer opportunities for Tasmanian farmers. The increased cost of stockfeed in times of drought, as we have experienced recently in Tasmania, will have a severe impact on the state's grazing and dairying industries.

There is one very positive action that the government can take with regard to this legislation to ensure industry security and, therefore, job security. It is an action that we on this side of the House would be only too happy to support—that is, it could enshrine the Tasmanian wheat freight subsidy in legislation. We are all aware that that will not mean the subsidy will exist forever. There may in the future be better ways to approach the issue of ensuring that value adding industries in Tasmania do not have to suffer significant freight cost disadvantage. What it would mean is that we would not have to depend on the whims of Treasury, who may see this scheme as an easy touch. The scheme would, quite rightly, become the responsibility of the federal parliament.

As I have already pointed out, a proper review process would have reference to the impact of the scheme on our economy and those directly affected Tasmanian industries. A proper review would fully consider issues regarding grain handling infrastructure. A proper review would have appropriate regard for the roles of both state and federal governments and Bass Strait transport infrastructure. And a proper review would seek to address the change of funding from a financial to a calendar year basis. The government must outline the process for review and, frankly, it must do it now. We are months down the track from when this review should have commenced. The government is putting industry on hold at a time when they are crying out for certainty. The viability of the industry and the security of the jobs of hundreds of Tasmanian workers depend on this government doing its job in actually reaching the targets and aims it sets for itself.

The Tasmanian Wheat Freight Subsidy Scheme is not in any way a drain on the government's coffers, but it is an incredibly vital scheme for Tasmania. We are a small community and the potential for damage to our small economy is huge—lost jobs and lost industries. The government must therefore give all those industries and the people they employ an assurance that the scheme will continue. The government must give some indication that it understands, however belatedly, the needs of Tasmania and the needs of those very important industries. These industries employ up to 1,600 Tasmanians directly or indirectly in bulk grain storage, handling and transport, animal feed milling, flour milling, poultry, pig meat, egg production, abattoirs and other associated process activities. These are vital for the Tasmanian economy and they are vital for Tasmanian jobs. I urge the minister to pay attention to this issue. I urge the government to set out what the terms of reference for the review will be and to actually get started on it.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to rise today to speak in this debate on the issue of volunteering. It is an issue that has emerged at the forefront of people's consciousness over the very successful period of the Olympics and the Paralympics and, with next year being the International Year of the Volunteer, it is appropriate for us as a federal government to consider how we should respond. I am very pleased to see that Minister Newman has announced very significant funding, in the order of $2½ million, which will enable each electorate to have some $5,000 to spend on supporting various volunteering programs. One of the great features of Australian life is the extent to which we have volunteers throughout our community. In fact, the range of volunteers is quite amazing. The last comprehensive survey of volunteers was in 1995, and it showed that 19 per cent of the civilian population aged 15 years or over at that time did some sort of voluntary work. Approximately 2,639,000 people were in some type of volunteer role. Rather interestingly, the highest level of volunteering was in the ACT, with 26 per cent of the ACT involved in volunteering. There are more females involved than males.

speech.para: The range of areas in which volunteers are involved is extensive. The number one area in which volunteers are involved is a formal organisation, the scout movement, which includes the Guides, Brownies and Cubs. The number two area is the surf clubs. In my own electorate of Cook we have four magnificent surf clubs and the extent to which they are staffed by volunteers, both to man patrols and to look after swimmers during the year, is very commendable. The number of surf clinics they hold, teaching young people from throughout the western suburbs as well as within the Sutherland shire, is extensive as well. There are sporting clubs generally, such as Rotary, Apex and Lions clubs. There is assistance to disabled groups. We have the Rainbow Club in my area, which assists people whose intellectual or motor function disablement affects their ability to swim.

In Australia generally, there are church groups, guides in art galleries and even within the parliament here there are groups of volunteers to show people around the building. There are bushfire fighters in the country fire services and the remedial reading helpers that go to schools. Meals on Wheels provides a very significant service to the older members of our community. Hospital aged care volunteers and the Pink Ladies assist the trained nurses, sisters and matrons in hospitals in a whole range of tasks.

We have various charitable groups assisting in a whole range of ways in our community. St Vincent De Paul, the Salvation Army and Mission Australia are charitable groups that go out night after night to provide shelter, meals and blankets for people on the streets. The Wesley Mission is involved in similar types of programs for those who have various emotional problems and for senior citizens in our community who are without housing. For those involved in drug programs there is suicide watch and counsellors through Lifeline. We have the state emergency services, St John Ambulance and parents and friends who assist in the running of schools. We have had the recent emergence of the Clean-up Australia campaign where volunteers go out on a Sunday and clean up their environment. The extent of voluntary work in Australia is unbelievable. When visiting other countries around the world we think of the impact our Australian volunteer movement could have on those countries.

In terms of my own role in the New South Wales Olympic bid—and I am glad to see the member for Hume here, who was also involved in it—when we were looking at what the Olympics could do for Sydney and Australia, we never quite anticipated the impact of the volunteers at the Olympics. I have talked to some of the IOC members who voted for Sydney and their highest commendations were for the venues that we provided—how outstanding they were compared to other Olympics; the crowd support—regardless of whichever team was playing and whether it was an Australian team or not, the crowd supported the teams playing, and that impressed the IOC enormously; and, finally, the volunteers. The IOC member from Ireland said to me that, in speaking about the success of the games in a broadcast to Ireland, he said it was the spirit of the volunteers more than anything else that impressed him about the Sydney Games and that it was the key defining feature of the Olympics.

Never before have the Olympic Games had so many volunteers—40,000 volunteers were way in excess of the number used in previous Olympics. I think the training carried out by TAFE also contributed to the success of the volunteers. It was done over three days. The first training day was locational, the second training day was on crowd control and the third training day was on relationships with the public. Of course, the volunteers were always cheerful and efficient. They carried out their important roles, whether it was checking for security or whatever, with a minimum of fuss.
