They did not succumb to the officialdom routine where people are given a little power and they abuse it. They did their job with great courtesy and a great sense of cheerfulness. Many people saw that in the way the volunteers operated, and they were terribly impressed. So, if there was one key defining feature of the Olympic Games, it was the volunteers. The volunteers came from all walks of life. There were people whom I knew who are doctors, lawyers, teachers, accountants, police inspectors, engineers and, of course, housewives and retirees who were out there involved in it all and loving it.

So the question now is: how can we tap into this vast resource? The Olympics have demonstrated that these people have an enormous amount to offer and that they want to contribute to the greater good. Only last Friday I heard the managing director of Touraust, which runs Chifley and Country Comfort Hotels, say that he would like to get a list of all of the volunteers in Sydney and offer them jobs as part of the hospitality team in hotels. We could use the volunteers in our international airports to greet people when they arrive, or use them downtown in our major cities to provide advice to tourists on how to get around our cities. There is no doubt that the Olympics and Paralympics have focused us on the whole question of voluntarism in Australia. My colleague Kay Elson said that in her electorate recently she put on a morning tea for volunteers with the Prime Minister and had some 1,100 people accept the invitation, some 700 of whom will be going at another time. Of course, part of the success was that the Prime Minister came and gave recognition to those people who contribute to the wider community on such a selfless basis.

Four types of volunteer organisations account for nearly 80 per cent of all the volunteer hours worked. They are welfare and community groups, which account for 24.4 per cent; sport and recreation groups, which account for 24.1 per cent; religious groups, which account for 16.3 per cent of the community; and education and training groups, which account for 14.1 per cent. As to where we go from here, perhaps a guidebook could be issued across Australia as to where volunteers can be used, the criteria that are needed for volunteers in the various services, how they can apply, and application forms so that positions can be centrally filled. Perhaps a volunteers web page would be useful, with all the various groups listed underneath as subsets. It would also be an opportunity for some of our retired people to get some self-fulfilment and to realise that they have an enormous amount to contribute.

In relation to the government's support for next year's International Year of Volunteers through its small grants programs, I would like to commend Minister Newman for the grants of $5,000 to local communities to assist and encourage volunteers to contribute to their communities in the wide range of activities in which they are currently involved. The Olympics showed what volunteers in Australia can do. I believe next year we have the opportunity to show the flame of volunteerism in Australia, which has been a great success in the past and will be so in the future.

subdebateinfo.title: Private Health Insurance
Goods and Services Tax: Small Business

subdebate.1.title: Goods and Services Tax: Small Business

talk.start.para: —Today I wish to bring to the attention of the House a few matters that I have come across in my electorate of Bowman. Firstly, I would like to raise matters relating to the government's incessant push for a predominantly private health system. The basis for this move is the government's preconceived notion that the private system will in some way cure all the ills of the public system. To this end, the government has redirected funds to its Lifetime Health Cover scheme—funds which, in my opinion, could have been better spent on improving our public system. My thoughts on this issue are strengthened when I talk to many of my constituents in Bowman who tell me that they have felt rushed into private health cover without any great knowledge on the issue. This, I suspect, is a symptom of the government's expensive and aggressive advertising campaign.

speech.para: One recent case that highlights the deficiencies of the private health insurance system involves my constituent Mrs Hazel White of Wellington Point. Recently Mrs White was required to undergo cartilage replacement surgery in her shoulder. This entails the placement of a Synvisc viscose supplement in her shoulder. I am told that this is quite a common form of treatment for sporting injuries in the shoulder and in the knee. The extent of the injury is such that she now requires this surgery every nine to 12 months. However, at a cost of approximately $444.50, and combined with the costs of the treatment which accompany the surgery, including injections every three months, this is quite an expensive process for Mrs White. As Mrs White is in top level private cover, she expected her health insurance would assist in meeting the costs of the treatment. I am told she has been in top cover for more than 20 years and in this time has rarely made a claim. However, I was surprised to learn that Mrs White cannot claim this procedure on her insurance. Quite understandably, she is left wondering why she bothers with private health insurance when it deserts her when she needs it the most.

A similar case involves my constituent Ms Lyn Schmidt of Manly and her mother who is battling against a progressive illness. Ms Schmidt cares for her mother at home in an attempt to improve her mother's quality of life. As part of her mother's treatment, Ms Schmidt is required to employ the use of an oxygen concentrator. Ordinarily, a patient would be hospitalised if they reached the stage that they needed this equipment regularly. However, as Ms Schmidt's mother wants to remain at home, the family agrees that they should do all that is possible to fulfil this wish. The cost of the concentrator is $325.85 per cylinder, of which approximately $116 is refunded by the private health insurer. That is a gap of almost $200, and these cylinders are replaced frequently. Again, this is a case where the patient has been in top level private health insurance for over 20 years.

Both of the cases I have mentioned suggest to me that private health insurance is failing in its obligations to its long-term members. Where is the sense in paying the huge amounts of money needed for insurance when the insurance companies fail to meet their obligations to long serving clients? In this context, the government's support for our private insurance system seems somewhat curious. If private health companies are unwilling to accommodate long serving, `blue ribbon cover' clients, how might we expect them to treat the flow of new basic cover clients who were scared into private health insurance by the government's misleading advertising campaign?

I remain unconvinced by the government's approach in this regard. It is obvious to me that an insurance company, whose primary motive is the bottom line, will have less of an interest in ensuring a universally accessible and affordable health system than a government would. Only a public body such as Medicare, with its focus on improving the health system rather than deriving profits, has the ability to meet these basic requirements. This is what makes the government's redirection of funds to encourage private health insurance all the more troubling. Medicare, not private health insurance, should be the focal point of any federal government strategy in relation to health and aged care. In this sense, I am proud that the opposition is proposing to ease the burdens on our public system by bolstering Medicare and introducing schemes such as Medicare after hours, which aims to alleviate the pressure on public emergency and aged care facilities.

I also want to raise a problem which exists in the small business community and amongst accountants in this country—that is, the effect that the new taxation system is having on small business in particular. I mention one gentleman, a certified practising accountant in my electorate of Bowman, in Cleveland, by the name of Campbell McCart of McCart and Co. I suggest that he would be one of many hundreds of accountants throughout this country that are suffering a similar problem. In a letter to me dated 2 November 2000 he stated—and with his permission I read this letter to the House:

quote.para: Dear Sir,
Re: EXTENSION TO LODGE BAS/IAS
As per the attached letter to the ATO—

speech.para: that is, the Australian Taxation Office—

quote.para: we have written asking for an extension to lodge.
We are sure you are aware of the pressure and stress that we as Accountants are currently working under.

We request that you contact the ATO on our behalf and request an extension to lodge on behalf of our clients and ourselves. Presently, we believe the ATO does not fully understand the increase in workload and difficulties that the introduction of GST has brought to accounting practices.
We acknowledge that we will not be able to meet the current deadlines. Accordingly, our clients who are members of your electorate will have penalties and interest charges imposed on them by the ATO.

speech.para: He then forwarded a copy of a letter which he had written to the taxation department, addressed to the Deputy Commissioner of the Australian Taxation Office, stating:

quote.para: Dear Sir,
RE EXTENSION TO LODGE BAS/IAS RETURNS

We hereby request that you grant our firm an extension to lodge the attached list of clients to the 15/12/2000. That these clients have no penalties or interest charges applied. We consider our request is not unreasonable based on the following reasons.

(A) GST has increased our workload greatly and we are having difficulties meeting our lodgement dates with our normal work. GST has swamped us with the extra work it requires from us in assisting our clients. Our firm in the past has always had an acceptable lodgement program with the ATO.

(B) With the limited resources available we have been working six days a week since January. The effect of this is that our staff and myself are beginning to get burnt out. I am sure the ATO is aware of the demands that has been placed on practitioners.

speech.para: He went on to state at the end:

quote.para: I look forward to you favourable response as I am sure you are aware of the difficulties involved.

speech.para: He has also given me the names of a number of small businesses in my electorate. Naturally, I will not read them out, but I do say this: what Mr McCart is complaining about quite legitimately is something which has been felt all around Australia. There is no doubt that it does not matter what sort of a business you are in. Small business has the extra burden of having to do these things. People want to conduct their businesses and they do not want to have to worry about filling out forms. Most of them are going to the accountants. One would normally think the accountants would be happy about that because there is a lot of extra money to be made, but the reality is that most of the accountants I speak to are very dirty about what has happened. It is not a question of politics—who you support and who you do not support. Obviously more thought had to go into the transitional period of the introduction of the GST. What Mr McCart is saying is simply: `Look, I'm not going to be in a position, like many other people, to be able to do exactly what the letter of the law says.'

Naturally, thousands of taxpayers and people in small businesses across Australia will be affected by this problem. Every time I have ever had anything to do with the Commissioner of Taxation, in Brisbane and elsewhere, or with the staff of the Australian Taxation Office, they have always bent over backwards to try to help. They are a bunch of caring people up there. Perhaps he can use that same care in dealing not only with the request of my constituent but also, I am sure, with the thousands of others who are writing to him with the same request.

A lot of care needs to be taken and a lot of compassion and understanding need to be shown to make sure that people who are in this position, particularly small businesses, do not end up not only having to cop the GST and find the money and make sure that they keep their cash flow going but also having to lodge the returns and do all the paperwork, when essentially it is not part of the core business that they undertake. So I ask the Taxation Office to look sympathetically at the request of my constituent, Mr McCart, and at the requests of the small businesses and people on behalf of whom he acts. I hope that a lenient and compassionate attitude can be taken in these first stages of the implementation of the goods and services tax.

talk.start.para: —Once again I rise in the grievance debate, as I did on 21 June in 1999 and also in the adjournment debate on 26 August 1999, to talk about an issue that is of real concern to wool producers and sheep and lamb producers in the electorate of Hume and, indeed, right across New South Wales and around Australia. That issue is ovine Johne's disease and the effect that ovine Johne's disease is having on the lives of these producers. In that debate on 21 June 1999, amongst other things, I made the comment that I had serious concerns about the `poorly handled, deteriorating fiasco that is the OJD problem in Australia'. Also in that grievance debate speech I raised the issue of a number of families that were in positions which placed enormous mental and financial stress on them and, more specifically, which placed a very real and ongoing financial imposition on them that nobody seemed to care about, particularly the New South Wales state Department of Agriculture.

speech.para: In that grievance debate speech in June 1999 I referred to a Tarago family who had had to live on a child's Austudy allowance to survive after their sheep had been detected with ovine Johne's disease and who had had a five-year quarantine placed on their property. I also talked about another constituent who underwent a faecal pool test. The owner was told that the outcome would not change their status of ovine Johne's disease, but that was an absolute lie. They ended up having a ovine Johne's disease status placed on their property, effectively shutting them down.

I then came back into this parliament on 26 August and talked once again about the issue of ovine Johne's disease and how it was affecting people and destroying their lives. In that adjournment debate speech I raised the issue of the way the New South Wales state government bureaucrats had ignored the statutory powers vested in the states specifically for the control of notifiable and other transmissible diseases and forced farmers and their veterinarians into common law agreements. They had removed safeguards and protection available under statute from farmers and their veterinarians, leaving them open to arrogant, and clearly nonsensical, direction from the state. I also referred to the extraordinary conduct of the state government, which had meant that retribution or punishment is feared by many people who might otherwise give evidence and that these individuals face the complete loss and destruction of their farming business or, in the case of veterinarians, the loss of their right to practise.

The issue, unfortunately, has not lessened. In fact, the problems of ovine Johne's disease have been further compounded. On numerous occasions I have tabled various examples of families who are emotionally and financially ruined by the disease. I have spoken about unfair tactics by the New South Wales state government in their handling of the disease and the way the federal government seems to wash its hands of all responsibility on this issue.

More recently I referred to correspondence which was forwarded to producers outlining the need for a voluntary payment of $100 by each producer to help support the Ovine Johne's Disease Program, otherwise known as the `ovine Johne's disease levy'. Aside from the hilarity of the attempts by the state government to make producers feel as if it were voluntary, the levy itself is a sombre and very real example of the state government's continuing attempts to make producers pay for the disease. Either the state government thinks property owners are fooled by the use of the word `voluntary' in the context of a payment that is actually compulsory or they are making a mockery of the situation.

Both the national Ovine Johne's Disease Program and the New South Wales management program have been criticised, and for good reason. Part of the problem with the state government's approach to this disease is that they keep changing the rules and, for some producers, these flippant changes of heart are having very real, very negative impacts on unsuspecting property owners. Recently, a very well-known family in the Yass district have been fined by the Department of Agriculture for failing to volunteer information to the Department of Agriculture which would create massive problems for other people. I would like to quote from a Town and Country Magazine article on this issue, from the week commencing 23 October this year. It was written by a well-known local identity who has the interests of rural people at heart, Mr Leon Oberg. He writes:

quote.para: The Privett family of Glenleigh Merino Stud at Yass is looking at every option including an appeal to their fines in Goulburn Local Court for two counts of failing to tender information required by NSW Agriculture.
The stud's principal, Graham Privett, was fined $5000 on each of those counts in Goulburn Local Court a week ago.
The outcome has stunned most sheep breeders.
Mr Privett told Town and Country Magazine while there have been talks with a high profile Queen's Counsel with an interest in the sheep industry, an appeal would cost at least $25,000.
He said the stud had already forked out $38,000 on the court action in addition to the cost of lost business and “the enormous stress involved”.
The story started when the Privett family had their stud sheep voluntarily tested for Ovine Johnes Disease in 1998. One sheep out of 476 allegedly tested positive.
Mr Privett refused to tell the Department who he had already sold sheep to.
“Glenleigh” was given “infected” status, meaning the family could no longer sell livestock to other merino breeders unless their flocks too had the disease.

speech.para: Here we have a situation where a well-known, respected family that has been in wool breeding for merino stock for many decades have been effectively put out of business because of the ovine Johne's disease suspect status on their flock, as a result of highly suspect testing procedures, and when they were threatened with legal action to disclose the names of people that they had sold stock to and refused to do so were immediately, through the bureaucratic process, subjected to further stress and economic and financial penalty by having their case taken to the court under prosecution through the New South Wales Department of Agriculture.

Finally, I say to the federal government: if you think that this matter is an isolated one and if you think that it is going to go away and disappear, it is not. If we do not do something to assist people like this well-respected grazier in the Yass district, then we are going to see more and more people being subjected to what he has been subjected to as a person trying to protect his industry and protect others. I am pleased to see that there has been a call from local producers to not pay their $100 so-called voluntary levy but to make that levy available in a pool to assist Mr Privett and his family obtain the finance needed to appeal the process and the decisions that have been imposed on him as a producer who has been subjected to the farcical situation of having his property declared ovine Johne's disease infected and effectively had his living and his right to trade and to continue to be a well-respected producer of fine wool in the Yass district taken away from him as a result of the heavy-handed and overzealous way in which the Department of Agriculture sought to make him an example of what they will do if people buck the system. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —This weekend marked the fifth anniversary of the assassination of the former Israeli Prime Minister, Yitzhak Rabin. It is timely to reflect on recent events in the Middle East. Since the visit in September to the al-Aqsa mosque by Ariel Sharon, a former Israeli defence minister and currently leader of the Likud Party, we have all seen shocking images of violence erupting in Jerusalem and the Palestinian territories. These clashes continued this weekend, invariably between Israeli troops and young Palestinians. Approximately 200 people, mostly Palestinians, have been killed and thousands injured. With Rabin's assassination by, as I would remind the House, a right-wing Israeli nationalist, he achieved martyrdom status. Who knows how events would have unfolded if he had not been killed at that crucial time during an election rally? No doubt Benjamin Netanyahu would not have become Prime Minister of Israel and then started derailing the peace process. I would remind the House that early in the 1990s there were secret negotiations organised by the Americans, in Oslo, between representatives of Rabin and Yasser Arafat, which resulted in the so-called Oslo accords under which the Israelis agreed to transfer territory in the West Bank and Gaza to Palestinian control in return for a wide-ranging peace deal. These agreements were ratified by the Israeli Knesset and the Palestinian legislative assembly. Rabin's murder in 1995 interrupted this process, which has struggled to survive ever since. And now we have this awful situation where young teenagers armed with stones are pitted against young soldiers in tanks firing machine guns.

speech.para: Last year I visited the Middle East and experienced first hand what it is like to be in this atmosphere of hatred, persecution and oppression. You have only to go through some of the checkpoints to see what is like—checkpoints between the Gaza Strip and Israel and between the West Bank and Israel. Palestinians are humiliated and harassed as a matter of course. The overwhelming Israeli military presence is a constant psychological pressure. You do not have to be an Arab to experience the unpleasant atmosphere; you just have to be there. I personally found it disturbing that so many Israelis carry weapons. I saw settlers with guns in the old city of Jerusalem. So many of these settlers are fanatics who have moved to Israel in comparatively recent times but want to go back to some notion of the biblical land of Israel. More often than not they are funded and otherwise supported by people who do not live in the Middle East. For example, Australia's Joe Gutnick has funded housing for Israeli settlers in Hebron—a large Arab city for hundreds of years.

To allegedly protect these settlers, 20 per cent of the city of Hebron is closed off and patrolled by Israeli military. Imagine the resources that have to be diverted to ensure the safety of these people. Surely they do not have to live there, and it is a deliberate provocation on the part of many of these settlers, intended to upset the Palestinians and cause trouble. Indeed, to go to the mosque in Hebron you have to go through a metal detector. You have to declare whether you have any guns on you. This is supposed to protect the Palestinians from the Israelis, because it was a deranged settler who murdered a number of people while they were at prayer in that mosque. But the people who are Palestinians have to go through the metal detectors.

I might give you some facts about Hebron to prove my point. In terms of population, it is the largest Arab town on the West Bank. There are over 405,000 people in the Hebron district, and nearly 120,000 in the city itself. There are 400 settlers in Hebron, protected by 2,000 Israeli soldiers. Overall, settlers represent less than seven per cent of the population of the Palestinian territories and less than three per cent of the population of Israel. Yet their needs—you could say demands—are always heard loud and clear, while the plight of the Palestinians is largely ignored.

What do we and the rest of the world see most often in the newspapers or on television about this conflict? What is the line we are fed nearly all the time? We are continually told that Israel, the regional superpower, is in a state of siege. But who from? Rock throwing adolescents and children? The media say that the Palestinians are unwilling to participate in the peace process and that they are being uncooperative and unreasonable. But even senior Israelis admit that Arafat wants peace. Even when we see photographs and television footage of a father trying to protect his young son from bullets, which, tragically, soon found their mark, we are told that the Palestinians virtually asked for it by being in that place at the wrong time. The story is twisted and manipulated. But in the end the truth remains: the helpless boy was gunned down and his father was wounded, not to mention the ambulance officer who was trying to reach them, who was also wounded. Surely the soldiers could have held their fire for the few seconds it would take for the boy and his father to get out of the line of fire. You would expect that soldiers of a democratic state would not be operating under rules of engagement that allowed them to shoot children and ambulance drivers. I would certainly expect that no soldiers of our state ever operated under those rules of engagement.

There are two sides to every story, and to my mind the Israeli version is not the only one. Nor is it the correct one. This dispute is not just about the claims or needs of Israelis. It is about the Palestinians also—people who have lived in this part of the world for thousands of years and who should be able to continue to live there without harassment and persecution. That is what it is: it is persecution and extreme provocation that has driven the Palestinian people to take the drastic steps that they have recently taken. Many of them feel that they have been driven to the point where they have nothing to lose: not even the thought of possible death deters them. I am told by journalists who have been there that young people in these demonstrations who are injured or wounded are taken to hospital and returned to the front line. What has driven them? You have only to look at the statistics to see how unbalanced the conflict is: since September, 200 people killed, thousands wounded, almost all of them Arabs. And some of these Arabs are Israeli citizens. This is a country that is turning its guns on its own citizens.

I mentioned the compelling image I saw last week on the television of a teenager throwing rocks at a tank firing a machine gun. To me this image—this bizarre reversal of the David and Goliath story—exemplified the problem. Why is all the sympathy in the West with the tank driver? Why aren't we all asking what has driven this young person to such desperation that he would engage an armed battle tank with stones? On the weekend Shimon Peres said he believed Yasser Arafat wanted peace. It is time that the Israeli government honoured the memory of Yitzhak Rabin by stopping the killing and starting the peacemaking.

talk.start.para: —I rise today to speak about Australia's taxation system and the need for incentive within that system. The National Party has always believed in the principle of reward for effort. This is in contrast to the Labor Party, who ditched any claim to the old ideal of a fair day's pay for a fair day's work when they defended and supported the behaviour of the waterfront union for decades. But I will not dwell on the failings of the Labor Party, because that would take far longer than the time I have available today.

speech.para: We must ensure that, when people work hard to receive greater rewards, they are not unfairly penalised by the taxation system. This government has already successfully undertaken the biggest overhaul of our taxation system since Federation, and that reform process was motivated by a need to make the tax system fairer for everyone in this country. However, there remains the question of inequity between city and country areas. This inequity has always existed, and rural people have—begrudgingly but they have—accepted slightly lower levels of service and so on, because they know they will never catch up to developments in the so-called `big smoke'.

The gap between city and country has grown to be more than a gap and is rapidly developing into a chasm. Thus there needs to be a mechanism to acknowledge the differences and there must be greater incentive for people to live and work outside the major cities. Through the zone rebate system, the government already recognises that people living in remote areas are at a disadvantage. According to the Australian Taxation Office, zone rebates are given in recognition of the disadvantages that taxpayers are subject to because of the uncongenial climatic weather conditions—that means either very, very hot or very, very cold—the isolation and the high cost of living in comparison to other areas of Australia.

However, this applies to many parts of regional Australia that are currently not eligible for the zone rebate. Also, rebates are a relatively ineffective means of compensating people for the disadvantages they face in country areas. I would like much greater scrutiny of the concept of zoned taxation as a system of encouraging working people and businesses to set up and remain in the bush. If the decision of the nation as a whole is to retain our regional populations and therefore have towns and cities spread across this wonderful nation, we need to back that decision with some sort of positive incentive scheme. We are talking here about changing a system where country based working people and particularly country businesses could get more money in their bank accounts from lower taxation.

Regional tax zoning would be the ideal incentive for a full revival of our small towns and country communities, not only in my electorate of New England or the electorate of the member for Parkes but all over regional Australia. Ideally, zoned taxation could mean a reduction of PAYE tax for country workers and a lower rate of company tax for business as an incentive to live and work in the country. I do recognise the fact that both company tax and PAYE tax have been reduced substantially from 1 July. I am very excited about the concept of zoned taxation, particularly as it could benefit New England, and I am giving the concept my full support. It is important to note that this is not some left-field proposition that has no standing in any other sphere of government activity. Many issues are dealt with in terms of zones or within similar frameworks. Government programs of many shades are targeted at specific community sectors, so there is no shortage of precedents in this matter.

The ways in which support can be provided to rural and regional Australia are twofold. We can have support programs and the like, many of which have made a valuable contribution to a great many communities, and I am obviously not calling for any reduction in that support. There have been many important announcements since this government was elected in 1996. Most recently, John Anderson, Leader of the National Party, unveiled the $90 million Regional Solutions Program to boost opportunities in regional Australia. This program targets regional and rural communities experiencing economic and social disadvantage, including high levels of unemployment and inadequate services. Flexibility is the key to the Regional Solutions Program. The program allows communities to identify and implement development opportunities that meet their specific needs, allowing them to find local solutions for local problems. This is a direct response to concerns of the Regional Australia Summit delegates that one-size-fits-all programs will not meet local needs in regional Australia. The program builds on other successful government initiatives such as the Rural Communities Program and the Rural Plan Initiative, and will assist regional communities to meet some of the challenges identified not only at the Regional Australia Summit but at the recent Northern Australia Forum. These programs return some of the tax dollars collected from regional Australia, which is only fair and just.

Like all people living and working in the country, I am grateful for these wonderful programs and the many other programs I have not mentioned here today because time does not permit. But we cannot rest on our laurels, because there is much to be done to repair the immense damage of 13 years of Labor neglect and their deliberate sabotage of regional economies. According to the Australian Bureau of Statistics, groups of people of low socioeconomic status tend to be over-represented in smaller towns and geographically isolated locations. This is because it is more difficult to travel a couple of hundred kilometres, with no public transport, to the next town in a search for work than it is to jump on a train in the city.

At the Regional Australia Summit, the Australian Council for Infrastructure Development Chief Executive Officer, Mr Dennis O'Neill, presented a paper that said bush communities are not as well served as their city cousins when it comes to basic infrastructure of water, telecommunications, airports, power, gas, road and rail. Social infrastructure—health, education, aged care, policing and community services—is also stretched. He said more work is needed to identify the status of current infrastructure stock and to distinguish between needs and wants. Mr O'Neill said the private sector has the capital, the innovation, the managerial capacity, the skills and the will to deliver, but there are barriers. While he did not specifically refer to taxation zones, he did say there needs to be greater incentive built into the tax system to encourage the growing role of private infrastructure and provide for co-funding between investors and local, state and federal governments. This will happen only when there is a clear financial incentive for the private sector to invest outside large metropolitan areas.

The Western Research Group, which has a charter of working to develop the western NSW economy, has recently called for the establishment of enterprise zones. A report from this group states that there is an imbalance between the prosperity of metropolitan areas and the disadvantage experienced in regional areas. To quote their report:

quote.para: This regional imbalance is the result of the failure of regional markets to provide employment and investment opportunities comparable to metropolitan markets. Europe and the US have had some success in addressing their regional problems through the use of Enterprise Zones, which create new employment, business and investment in regional areas with the use of special tax incentives.

speech.para: This report develops the enterprise zone index as a measure of regional disadvantage. The application of an enterprise zone policy, under specified assumptions, creates a fiscal saving for the federal government. Each individual that is transferred from unemployment to employment improves the bottom line of the federal budget. The fiscal saving grows with the increase in the enterprise zone employee's wages. Given that a successful enterprise zone would reduce unemployment, decrease regional disadvantage and improve the bottom line of the federal budget, it is a policy tool that should be investigated in greater depth. A more comprehensive index could be developed to select disadvantaged areas of rural and regional Australia. A model of tax incentives could also be developed with a range of measures to be used in a pilot enterprise zone. This would allow an estimation of the actual benefits and costs of enterprise zones and how effective tax incentives are in stimulating private enterprise. An effective enterprise zone policy could be used to correct market failures and promote regional balance. Enterprise zones promote the partnership of government, business and regional communities in an effort to shape the market outcomes for the national objectives of full employment and economic growth, the report said. These are goals that are totally consistent with my goals and those of the National Party, and I will be urging my colleagues to examine the concept in greater detail. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: (Mr Andrews)—The question is that grievances be noted.
(Mr Andrews)—I have received advice from the Chief Government Whip that he has nominated members to be members of certain committees.

motion.para: That:

talk.start.para: —On Thursday, prior to the interruption of this debate, I raised an issue regarding taxpayers called Absolute Homecare, who had applied to the replyin5 service, which was supposed to give a written ruling regarding various issues within five days of a taxpayer actually raising them. I noted at the time that these particular taxpayers had raised an issue with the ATO on 23 July 2000 and had still not had a reply three months later, even though they were supposed to have something in five days. Well, the taxpayers have had a win. I am pleased to report today that I have had notification that the Absolute Homecare people have received their ruling. Well done to the ATO for getting that prompt reply to the Absolute Homecare people!

speech.para: On Thursday I also touched on the impact of the GST on the housing sector. But the GST is also impacting on the commercial property market. We now have confirmation that projects in Western Australia have been put on hold or seriously jeopardised because of the impact of the GST. This means jobs in construction have been lost and investment in regional Australia has also been lost, all because of the GST. Again, this impact comes about specifically because of the GST: these projects—major projects in Kalgoorlie, one in Busselton and another in Bunbury—are all on hold because of a specific ruling on the GST. The ruling is that, where investors buy individual apartments and then lease them to hotel operators to be used as commercial accommodation—that is, as hotel rooms—these units will be treated as residences rather than as commercial properties. This is the case even though the properties cannot be used as a residence, either under the agreement with the operator or under the zoning laws of the areas concerned. This means that the GST associated with the purchase is not available as a credit to the purchaser, hence threatening the viability of the developments.

This anomalous result has arisen because of the law introduced here by the Treasurer. The Taxation Office has made rulings consistent with the law, and it is appropriate that this matter be raised now while we are looking at the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 8) 2000 second reading amendment. I would like to quote from a letter that I have received from the Kareelya property group, who are involved in these sorts of developments in Western Australia. I will be making some comments as I go. It says:

quote.para: GST—Commercial Residential Premises
Application of GSTR 2000/20 to Strata Titled Hotels

The issue by the Australian Taxation Office (the “ATO”) of GST Ruling GSTR 2000/20, firstly as a draft ruling in April 2000 and then as a final binding public Ruling on 21 June 2000, has created unprecedented concern for the developers of purpose built strata titled tourist hotels and resorts across Australia, particularly those located in regional areas.

This Group, like many others, is affected by the Ruling and it is therefore appropriate for me to outline the detrimental effect the Ruling will have on tourism based investment and job creation in regional areas generally, and the particular effect it is having on at least 4 development projects this Group has under way in Busselton, Bunbury, Kalgoorlie and Geraldton.
Currently we have under development the following projects in regional Western Australia:
an 88 strata titled unit/bungalow resort style hotel in Busselton;
a 76 strata titled apartment, business traveller oriented, resort style hotel in Kalgoorlie;
a mixed hotel, residential and commercial development involving the construction of in excess of 120 hotel suites in Bunbury; and
a 40 unit serviced apartment and 100 room hotel development in Geraldton.
All up, these developments represent capital expenditure exceeding $130,000,000—

speech.para: that is right, $130 million—

quote.para: in regional Western Australia. The projects under way are being developed either wholly, or substantially, as managed investment schemes regulated under the Managed Investments Act 1998. In essence, investors are invited to acquire strata titled units/apartments in the developments and by doing so they acquire interests in the relevant managed investment. In these hotel developments, the owners lease their strata titled units to a Responsible Entity licensed by the Australian Securities and Investments Commission (in this case, Kareelya Investments Limited) who appoints a separate hotel operator to manage all the units in the particular development as a complete hotel. Under this type of arrangement, the Responsible Entity/Operator pools the income, shares the expenses and distributes the net income back to the owners in predetermined proportions.

speech.para: There is a restriction on residence, which is very important. The letter says:

quote.para: It is a common feature of these hotels that the owners cannot reside in their units because of State Planning Commission and local council zoning and town planning conditions imposed on the developments. The units must be used only for short stay accommodation. It is therefore clear that an owner cannot `reside' in his unit, within the normally accepted common usage and meaning of that word.

In every case the strata units are currently, or will be, marketed as investment properties and every owner purchases one in the clear knowledge that he can never use it as a place of residence. In addition, investors purchase their units on the basis that they may enter into a lease with the Responsible Entity of the managed investment scheme for up to 8 terms of 10 years, so that all the units in the development can be operated as a complete hotel. An owner cannot unilaterally withdraw his unit from the hotel income-pooling scheme and operate the unit independently from the Responsible Entity.

speech.para: Concerning the structure of the investment, the letter states:

quote.para: When purchasing a strata title unit in one of the developments, the owner benefits from the terms of the various contractual documents that govern the ownership of his unit and its participation in the income-pooling scheme. These documents usually include a Constitution and Compliance Plan for the Scheme, as well as a form of income-pooling agreement or profit share lease. These documents, particularly the income-pooling agreement or profit share lease clearly, set out the terms under which the owner leases his unit to the Responsible Entity/Operator and to determine, to some extent, whether the supply by the owner of his unit will be a taxable supply for GST purposes, rather than an input taxed supply.

speech.para: They had GST advice before they proceeded and the letter says:

quote.para: Based on proper professional advice, this Group took the view that the types of strata units offered for sale in the developments were clearly commercial residential premises. This is a view that was adopted by virtually all, if not all, other developers offering similar type products. As a result, the Scheme documents we had prepared for our Schemes on this basis and did not seek to rely on very specific provisions in the GST law that may have reinforced the fact that the owners would make a taxable supply when they leased their units to the Responsible Entity of the Scheme.

speech.para: The units were then sold on that basis. The letter continues:

quote.para: The release of the GSTR 2000/20 has now created considerable uncertainty with regard to our developments and, no doubt, with regard to many other developments as well.

In GSTR 2000/20 the ATO has ruled that the units acquired by investors in these types of developments will be regarded as `residential premises' and not `commercial residential premises' for GST purposes. As such, the owners will not be entitled to GST input tax credits for any GST included in their purchase price. This will have a significant effect on the marketability of this type of investment, particularly those located in the regional areas of WA in which this Group is operating.

It is important to note that an owner of residential premises (such as a house) who rents his premises direct to a tenant is not required to pay GST on the rent he receives. Correspondingly, the tenant does not pay GST on the rent that he pays to occupy those premises. In this situation, it is appropriate that the owner is not entitled to GST input tax credits for the GST included in his costs, including the purchase price of the house.

This should be contrasted with the situation of the owner of a strata titled unit in a hotel. In this situation, the tenant of the owner's unit, being a guest in the hotel, must pay GST in his room charge yet the owner cannot obtain input tax credits for the GST included in his costs. This gives rise to a situation where GST is borne by both the supplier (the owner) and the recipient (the guest), rather than only by the end consumer which should be the result and which is the whole foundation—

speech.para: apparently—

quote.para: of the GST.

speech.para: The problem is basically one of legislation. The legislation does not adequately cater for this situation. If the legislation is not amended quickly, then clearly it will lead to an anomalous situation. The letter continues:

quote.para: On the one hand, a hotel owner who owns all the units in a strata title hotel will be entitled to input tax credits for the GST included in all his costs, thereby ensuring that all GST associated with the supply of accommodation is borne by the hotel guests. This should be contrasted with the situation in a hotel comprised of strata titled units owned individually by different owners where only some of the GST associated with the supply of accommodation will be borne by guests. This is because the owners will also bear some of the GST cost which relates to the GST included in their costs including the purchase price.

It is interesting to note that the practical application of the ATO's Ruling will mean that a development which comprises the construction of a residential premises (strata titled units) because the units will be sold to individual investors, changes to commercial residential premises when those units, without any change in character, ownership and use, are aggregated together and operated collectively as a hotel. This surely is not a result that was intended in the drafting of the GST legislation.

speech.para: In relation to the legislative solution, the letter goes on:

quote.para: While we believe that the problem may be overcome through the use of long-term leases, this is not the best solution because some uncertainty will still remain. This will still be so even if a private ruling is sought from the ATO on the effectiveness of the 50-year lease approach. The tourism property development industry requires far more certainty than is currently available if it is to continue to make investment, create jobs, bring new projects on stream and sell strata titled units in those projects to investors.

What is really needed is a legislative solution through amendment to the GST law to bring within the scope of commercial residential premises, the type of strata titled units that are sold to investors on the basis that they will form part of a purpose built hotel, motel, inn, hostel or boarding house.

speech.para: I am informed that the changes necessary to amend this legislation in this respect are very simple. Of course, they would have to be very simple in order for the government to understand them and even to comprehend them. Unfortunately, the government has refused to act. To return to the letter, Brett Jackson, the Director of Kareelya, states in his conclusion:

quote.para: This group has been a strong supporter of investment and commitment to the development of hotels in regional Western Australia. This commitment has already led to many millions of dollars of investment, as well as the future investment involved with our current projects. It is unquestionable that this investment will create significant economic activity and job creation in regional Australia at a time when there are widespread calls for greater commitment to regional Australia.

In the absence of any change to the Ruling, which appears unlikely, based on the subsequent privately rulings issued by the ATO, or legislative amendment, the detrimental effect on our industry will be significant. It is most likely that the ATO's Ruling, if maintained, and in the absence of a legislative amendment to make the position of individual strata title of hotel property owners unequivocal, will inhibit investment in tourist infrastructure in regional Australia.

speech.para: I am informed that the group contacted people at the `highest level of government'. When they contacted the highest level of government, they were told, `Yes, we believe you have a case and we are quite happy to follow this up for you. We believe that an amendment should be made to the legislation.' We are yet to see it. As far as I can see, absolutely no action has been taken whatsoever. I am also informed that this group and others approached the ATO and discussed the matter with one of the assistant commissioners. The advice given was that they also believed that the ruling was unfair and was based on legislation that needed to be changed but that it was not up to the ATO to change the legislation; it is a responsibility of government. However, it is affecting this particular group. What are the coalition members doing for the people in regional Western Australia? Look at Bunbury and Busselton: obviously both of those developments should be of interest to the member for Forrest. I have not heard the member for Forrest say anything whatsoever in relation to this matter, nor have I seen him do anything for these particular developments. And then we have Geraldton, which is in the electorate of the Minister for Forestry and Conservation, the member for O'Connor. I suppose it would be very hard for the minister to get off his logging truck, to do anything except bulldoze old-growth forests and to achieve something worth while for his local community, but it is high time he did. As an ex-Geraldton resident, I know that Geraldton needs a development of this sort, and it is high time the minister supported those people.

Then we move on to the development in Kalgoorlie. I am informed that the group did see the member for Kalgoorlie—I am not sure if they have seen the members for Forrest and O'Connor. The member for Kalgoorlie promised them in all sincerity that he would act on their behalf and deal with their issue. But, to my knowledge and certainly to their knowledge, the member for Kalgoorlie has done nothing. It is not like we are talking about a small issue that involves a small number of people—which I believe would be equally important. We are dealing here with projects in regional Western Australia worth a staggering $130 million. To date the government and the members representing the areas where those developments are occurring have done nothing. I call on the government to act now: amend this legislation and remove this burden from this vitally important sector of our business community.

talk.start.para: —The Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 8) 2000 is an important piece of legislation because it goes to the heart of the credibility of the Treasurer's attack on roll-back. The Treasurer is critical of Labor because, four months after the introduction of the new tax system, Labor have not yet produced a detailed breakdown of what we mean by the term `roll-back'. My response to that would be: if the Treasurer were interested in the substance of the issue and the logic of our position, rather than delivering simply another rendition of a third-rate piece of parliamentary melodrama as if he were still debating in the Carey Baptist Grammar School debating society, he would recognise the following points. The first is that it would be fiscally irresponsible for us to provide detail on this measure until we have some sense of the likely full-year effect on revenues occasioned by the introduction of the GST and by the taxation changes brought about as a consequence of that tax.

speech.para: The second concerns the adequacy of the compensation package afforded to low and fixed income earners. There is continuing uncertainty as to the full-year inflationary impact of the changes which have been brought about as a result of the GST package. Government members have already seen in their various electorates the debacle of the pensioner savings bonus. As for the government's completely premature triumphalism about the first round of inflationary numbers post July, I think it will be very interesting indeed to see the full flow-through effect of the fuel price hike on the cost of goods and services and the impact of the end of cost absorption by the small business sector in particular, given an emerging body of anecdotal evidence that at the moment a lot of small businesses are engaging in a post GST competitive shakeout. That is, there are a whole lot of small businesses out there in Australia currently absorbing costs, existing on the basis of extended lines of bank credit, hoping that their competitors fall over before they do, before engaging in cost clawback against consumers. My view on this question is that it is something on which the Treasurer had best `watch this space' rather than triumphantly proclaim that the inflation genie has been well contained within the bottle, because that is premature enthusiasm indeed—more on this a little later.

A third reason, going to the logic of why Labor has yet to enunciate its detailed elements of roll-back, concerns the precise long-term impact of the compliance burden on small business occasioned by the introduction of this package. When we talk about the compliance burden, we are not talking about simple questions such as registering for an ABN. We are not just talking about BAS compliance. We are not just talking about monthly and quarterly instalments, nor are we just talking about the calculation of input tax credits for refund purposes. We are talking about the entire burden which small businesses face in terms of the time and money they spend in complying with the new arrangements which have been imposed on them by government.
Let us take just one piece of commentary on thatthe piece in today's Financial Review by Jason Clout titled `Refund claims could spark audits':

quote.para: The Tax Office has been auditing monthly BAS lodgers if they claim a substantial refund. This is despite its repeated stance of taking a lenient approach with the GST in its early days.
The small business sector is concerned that a major tax crackdown is looming as the Federal Government struggles with a Budget cost blowout.
A spokesman for the Tax Office confirmed it was contacting businesses which claimed large refunds. But he said the contacts were part of the ATO's checking procedures rather than a full-blown audit.
`We are calling and in some cases visiting the business if they claim a large refund,' the spokesman said.

The checking program was necessary because credit claims were a major fraud risk, he said. The Tax Commissioner, Mr Michael Carmody, has said countries that introduce a GST-style tax often have to deal with inflated input tax credit claims. Large claims for sales tax refunds would also be scrutinised.
The ATO spokesman declined to nominate the audit threshold, although some accountants believe a claim of $5,000 will trigger an audit.
Ms Anna Carabao, tax partner at William Buck, said any business which claimed a large refund could `expect a knock on the door'.
`It's hard to even get the ATO to hand over a refund. One of our clients has waited for more than a month to get their money back,' she said.

speech.para: Mr Clout's report in today's Financial Review provides nothing but cold charity and scarce comfort for small businesses as they look at how the ATO is going to be administering their refund claims against the first round of BAS declarations.

But it does not stop there. We have heard in this parliament the Treasurer scoffing at our comment made often in this place that what in fact the government will face on the GST's implementation is a slow burn. What we have had in contrast is, I think, a comprehensively stupid observation from the Treasurer that the GST has been one undiluted implementation triumph. The skies have not fallen in but neither did Labor predict that the skies would fall in. What we have detected, however—and small business are shouting this from the rooftops—is that across small business and across the country at the moment we have emerging a massive hole in the roof. And who has belled the cat on this issue most recently? We heard the Treasurer in the parliament last week trumpeting a recent report by Morgan and Banks on just how wonderfully the government's package had gone down. Obviously the Treasurer did so prior to examining closely the Morgan and Banks job index poll which was published in yesterday's Sunday Telegraph. It is a document which is worthy of some quotation of itself. The article is titled `Profits Dive' and is on the front page of yesterday's Sunday Telegraph. It says:

quote.para: Nearly 95 per cent of Australian businesses say the GST has hurt their profits. A poll to be released today of almost 6000 small, medium and large employers has found overwhelming dissatisfaction with the GST on the four-month anniversary of its introduction.
The poll, conducted by the Morgan & Banks Job Index, is the first comprehensive report card on the GST from a business perspective.
The Morgan & Banks survey found 94 per cent of businesses nationwide believed their profits had suffered.
`It's costing people money,' Morgan & Banks director Ian Burns confirmed. `A lot of companies spent an absolute bomb implementing it.' `There's also the ongoing cost of administration.'
The hardest hit industries, according to the survey of 5877 employers nationally, are the utilities, chemical and oil, education and engineering sectors.
The overwhelming majority of businesses surveyed indicated they had experienced a downturn in profitability because of the GST,' Mr Burns said.
And 94.4 per cent of businesses with more than 20 but fewer than 200 employees said they had been badly affected.

speech.para: That is not the Australian Labor Party speaking; that is Australian business speaking. That is 6,000 Australian firms speaking, firms which have had to cope with the first quarter of the implementation impact of the GST package, as polled professionally through Morgan and Banks—Morgan and Banks being precisely the authority which the Treasurer quoted with gay abandon in this place last week as providing him with some sort of collateral underpinning for the overall implementation effect of the package.

TLAB8 goes to the heart of this compliance issue. When you look at its detail, TLAB8 is itself roll-back incorporated. The Treasurer daily seeks here to amuse—I think unsuccessfully—his backbench with our position on roll-back. Yet at the same time he rolls into this parliament, in this single piece of legislation, another 188 items of roll-back, adding to the 1,462 items of roll-back already rolled through the parliament since the passage of the principal ANTS bills—a grand total of how many? One thousand, six hundred and fifty roll-back items. On this question the Treasurer is the roll-back kid. He is the author of roll-back incorporated—a roll-back executed with all the coherence, system and intellectual rigour, I have to say, of a very large bowl of spaghetti.

What is the method in the 1,650 amendments so far before the House? Where is the method in the madness? Where is the rigour in the overall Costello schema of roll-back? It is very hard to find, really. If there is a central organising principle it seems to me to be something along these lines: get in the door to the Treasurer's office quick smart, particularly if you are from an organised lobby group, or get to the `Costello for Prime Minister' group as quickly as possible and, whacko, Bob's your uncle. That seems to be the only coherent and consistent principle that I can detect in the various elements of roll-back that we have seen rolled through this chamber in the last several months.

This, of course, opens up the broader question of what sort of Treasurer we are dealing with in this parliament. We have a Treasurer who lampoons roll-back when enunciated by Labor but who himself is roll-back incorporated. We have a Treasurer who lampoons a 72c dollar under Labor as some sort of national disgrace, but he thinks a 52c dollar under his stewardship as Treasurer just requires a little bit of market tweaking—the odd after-dinner speech in New York and Washington is designed to fix that up, squeezed in between the rigours of a Hudson River cruise with, it seems, a failed Republican candidate. We have a Treasurer who says that gross debt under Labor was a recipe for hauling in the IMF to fix up the economy. Yet, under the Liberals, where we have gross debt vastly in excess of that, under his watch as Treasurer, it is, from his perspective, just a bit of extra loose change.

We have a Treasurer who solemnly tells us now that he has a solemn policy never to comment on the currency. But I seem to recall that this same Treasurer set off a medium-level currency crisis a couple of years ago—in a fit of hubris after meeting the chairman of the Fed, Alan Greenspan—when he revealed to the media contents of what was supposed to be a confidential briefing from the chairman of the Fed. International currency markets now buckle their seatbelts every time our Pete goes to New York or to Washington, because if there is a major central bank near, and a major currency under discussion, who knows what the impact is going to be. Someone from New York said to me recently that whenever our Treasurer Costello goes to New York, the dealing rooms have a Costello alert, which rings so that appropriate hedging can be undertaken and no-one finds themselves short as a result of any unauthorised briefing which the Treasurer might provide to the media or others after any confidential meetings.

We see all these elements of what the Treasurer has been up to—saying one thing and doing another—right across the breadth of economic policy, yet we are supposed to take this Treasurer seriously. What sort of Treasurer are we dealing with these days? What does he stand for? The Treasury portfolio would have to be, after the prime ministership, the most important portfolio across the whole of government. There have been doubts cast on this score for quite some time, going right back to the Treasurer's days as shadow Treasurer—back in those halcyon days when we had the dream team of Downer and Costello. Do we all remember that, or is it just a bad part of our collective memory?

talk.start.para: —It was a nightmare.

—It was in fact, as my colleague the member for Lalor said, more than a dream; it was a nightmare. I would like to read from a report from the Sydney Morning Herald—five years old but, I think, worthy of some recount this evening—by Karen Maley. It is all about the Treasurer's performance prior to taking his position on the Treasury bench. Karen Maley writes:

quote.para: Economics is not a difficult subject. It does not require the sustained intellectual effort needed for, say, Wittgenstein's Tractatus Logico Philosophicus or Hegel's Phenomenology of the Mind. In terms of conceptual difficulty, it is child's play compared with particle physics or molecular biology.
And, although some argue that the arguments employed in economics are implausible, no-one claims that they are incomprehensible.
Why, then, has Peter Costello been so mediocre as shadow Treasurer?

speech.para: The article goes on:

quote.para: Nor can Costello argue that it's the fate of shadow treasurers to be dismissed. After all, his immediate predecessor in the job, Alexander Downer, won widespread acclaim for his performance ...

speech.para: That is an interesting reflection on history. I seem to recall contemporaneously that it was probably right. It goes on:

quote.para: ... Costello appears to believe that economics is merely another, slightly more sophisticated, form of name-calling, and that the main challenge in being shadow Treasurer is to come up with fresh forms of abuse for the Government.

speech.para: This insightful article goes on:

quote.para: The trouble with this behaviour is that few believe that Costello has actually taken the time to sit down and work out any solutions for our economic problems. His sole purpose is to bag the Government—

speech.para: the Keating government—

quote.para: and his interest in the subject seems to evaporate as soon as he has delivered his tightly-scripted lines in front of the television cameras. He's the meretricious actor ... Indeed, Costello has given absolutely no indication that he has any deep-seated beliefs on the subject. Behind the glib lines there is a worrying lack of sincerity. He's very much the barrister from central casting who, having flicked through his brief, puts in a polished performance, boots the other side, and collects his fee. But, he'd happily do the same for the other side if they were paying his fee.

speech.para: I seem to recall his earlier time in Young Labor and where he went from there. As I said, that was written some five years ago but, I think, it has an uncanny resemblance to the performance we see on the other side of this chamber on the part of the Treasurer today. In fact, when we see the Treasurer perform on economic and tax policy questions today, we usually see two types of delivery. We see type A, which I would describe as pre-rehearsed derision, for those of us on this side, but then we see the type B performance, which I would describe as mock sincerity and concern—a type I do not think the parliament has really seen, at full throttle at least, since Andrew Peacock's really serious look—making us all want to ask: one day would the real Peter Costello stand up and tell us what he actually believes in?

When talking about leadership politics on the other side of this chamber, it is interesting to look at the Treasurer and the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. When it comes to the minister for workplace relations, we might not like what he stands for on industrial relations—the destruction of organised labour—but at least we know that is what he stands for. When the Treasurer stands up and gives us a rendition of tax policy or economic policy in the broad, it is, frankly, very hard to pick exactly what constitutes his overall policy framework. In fact, five years on, the article to which I just referred seems to resonate and ring true.

The core of TLAB 8, which we have before the parliament now, goes to a number of Costello's individual roll-backs. It goes to an increased capacity to cancel GST registrations, changes in the manner in which tax debts are offset against GST refunds, an increased capacity to revoke monthly tax period elections, and many more such changes. Let us look at just a couple of those.

One of my Neighbourhood Watch groups recently approached me with concern about how they had become inadvertently caught up in the GST-BAS cycle. They had mistakenly applied for GST registration at the time that they had applied for their ABN. As a result, this particular Neighbourhood Watch, which does a very fine job on the south side of Brisbane, was recently required to submit a BAS. Its income for the first quarter was the princely sum of $94. After taking into account what the Neighbourhood Watch had concluded as an input tax credit, they concluded, based on advice from a part-time accountant who had given them some assistance, that they may be liable for a GST of $7. Why is it that Neighbourhood Watch groups have found themselves caught up in this mad system of taxation in the first place? Surely they are voluntary and charitable organisations. When this Neighbourhood Watch group approached my office and we, in turn, approached the Australian Taxation Office for some clarification on this issue—namely, are Neighbourhood Watch groups ITECs, that is, income tax exempt charities—we were told that it was far from clear and that they would be seeking guidance on the question.

So much for a rolled gold, beaut, no problems, no questions asked implementation period four months down the track, when your average local Neighbourhood Watch, who do a fine job right across this country, cannot get clear guidance from their local tax office as to whether they are a tax exempt or a non-tax exempt charitable body. I would say to the Treasurer: if there is still doubt four months down the track about where Neighbourhood Watch groups stand, what hope have we for the rest of the system, particularly as it applies to small business?

So much for the inadvertent registration for the GST! What about business activity statements—the world's simplest 148-page quarterly tax return? It all comes to a head on 11 November, Remembrance Day, when the first quarterly BAS is due. I predict that the small business sector will indeed be remembering the Howard government on 11 November. But I doubt that their remembrance will be of a particularly fond nature. The commentators on this question have been unified in their condemnation of the implementation by the tax office. There is commentary by Allesandra Fabro in the Financial Review. We have commentary from Kate Marshall, also in the Financial Review, and from Kathy Lipari from the Daily Telegraph. We also have a recent article by Christopher Jay, again from the Financial Review. Most recently, we have articles from Fiona Buffini and again Allesandra Fabro, all pointing to the enormous difficulties that small businesses face with the BAS system, and the management of refunds in particular.

What the Treasurer has forgotten in all of this is his responsibility as the Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Australia to properly administer the tax system. It is not just coming up with new policy; it is ensuring that the implementation of that policy is manageable through the tax office and through the accountancy profession for those who depend on that advice to make their businesses tick for the benefit of this country. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —In the minutes remaining before the dinner suspension, I will commence my remarks on the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 8) 2000. Those who observe this House routinely—hopefully, that is not too many in some senses—will know that, during question time, the Treasurer has a little party trick that he likes to use: he comes in and very theatrically rolls his `Rs' when talking about Labor's pledge to roll back the GST. It is very endearing in some senses.
—He is an endearing ham!

—He is an endearing ham. One wonders whether he has an Actors Equity card; although, I think they would probably have a quality control standard that would keep him out. Perhaps he still has his barrister's card and he got his skills in practice. One wonders why he bothers with all of this theatrical carry-on. I do not actually see too many members of his backbench laughing, and we have heard it so many times we are not laughing anymore. You wonder why someone would come in and so theatrically and so deliberately oppose a plan, which will be put forward by the Labor Party, to make the GST fairer and simpler. What could be wrong with that? Why would you come in and carry on in that fashion when you are up to your eyes yourself in roll-back? This Treasurer is constantly engaged in rolling back the GST, and this Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 8) 2000 is just the most recent example of roll-back according to the Treasurer.

speech.para: The bill contains 188 amendments, and seven more were circulated in the chamber last time we sat. That brings it to a grand total of more than 1,650 amendments to the GST. So the number just keeps on growing and sooner or later, no doubt, will crack the 2,000 figure. So, if the Treasurer wants to ridicule roll-back during question time, it is about time he woke up and realised that the joke is on him. Just so that people understand the nature of the roll-back with which we are dealing, I will briefly go to some of the details of this bill. I will not do it at too great a length because we would not want everybody to fall asleep. But you need to understand the mind-numbing complexity that this roll-back, induced by the Treasurer, is getting us into with our tax system. Schedule 1 deals with matters like changing input tax credits; changing the provisions that relate to child care; making the treatment of travel agents' fees for arranging overseas supplies such as accommodation, transport, car hire, sightseeing and what-have-you GST free; providing that a supply of a freehold interest or long-term lease made after a short-term lease is also GST free; providing that the sale of residential premises that have been used as residential premises for at least five years will be input taxed; and changing arrangements in relation to machines that take coins.

But that is not all. We have schedule 2, which deals with such matters as ensuring that re-imported breeding livestock is subject to GST only on the increasing value. Schedule 3 deals with various FBT tax matters. Schedule 4 deals with adjustments and, significantly, schedule 5 deals with a very clear error that was made at the outset of this legislation which prevents an entity that had registered for the GST being able to cancel that GST registration if it was inappropriate. Currently, such an entity is stuck with being registered, and with all the onerous compliance burden that goes with that, for 12 months. So that very manifest problem is being rectified by this bill. So you can see from that very quick tour of the provisions of this bill that it is, once again, layer of complexity upon layer of complexity and that, of course, is the essence of the GST roll-back according to this Treasurer and this government. It is not making the system fairer and simpler; if anything, it is making it more opaque.

Of course, we know as we move around our electorates how business is reacting to this tax system—how it is reacting to its complexities, its amendments, its more bits of paper and its increased changes. We have had the Morgan and Banks survey, which has already been referred to today. But the details of that are truly extraordinary: that you can have, when you survey almost 6,000 employers in a survey form that has been viewed as very reliable over the years, so many of them come up and say they really believe that the GST has impacted negatively on their organisation's profitability. The Morgan and Banks survey shows us that a whopping 94.1 per cent of businesses fervently believe that—`fervently' being their term, not mine. Of course, there are some differences in the various sectors, but even the sectors that are least affected are in the order of 84.3 per cent for services, 88.6 per cent for resources and 89 per cent for non-profit organisations. So bad is this survey that figures like that are viewed as a good result.

When you have in the upper ranges above 80 per cent of businesses in any sector telling you that the GST will negatively impact upon their profitability, I do not think that it can be viewed by anyone as a good result. What it is showing us is that business in this country is really struggling and is fearful of this tax system. The survey goes on to tell us that 12.3 per cent of Australian employers have indicated that their first GST payment to the government, which is due on 11 November, will cause cash flow problems. That has to be a real worry too. When we look through the detail of that, we can see that more than one-fifth of those in retail, more than one-fifth of those in tourism and more than one-fifth of construction and property firms are saying that they will have a cash flow problem caused by the GST. One wonders, when that cash flow problem strikes, precisely what impact we are going to see on employment and on business bankruptcies. One can only presume from this survey that we will see a very negative impact on employment and on business profitability. So I do not think that theatrical gestures and a little question time play can really give anybody any reassurance about what is going to happen as we pass the 11 November deadline and businesses start for the first time to really struggle with the implementation of this GST.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: —Before the suspension for dinner I had referred to the Morgan and Banks survey of small business attitudes in relation to the GST. That is not the only indicator we have of small business attitudes. The Victorian Parliament's Economic Development Committee has inquired into the issue of GST compliance. It found that Victorian small businesses are struggling to stay afloat as GST compliance costs balloon to more than $1.2 billion—that is its figure—and it put this down to a crippling cocktail of higher electricity, fuel and gas prices pushed up by the new tax. The committee said that this had already triggered a spate of closures of businesses in regional areas. The Herald Sun quotes from the committee's report:

quote.para: GST can be seen as a contributing factor in accelerating the closure of some small businesses.

speech.para: The Herald Sun reported that the committee:

quote.para: ... found businesses faced a compliance nightmare with setting-up costs of $5,000 to $20,000, and administration costs expected to soar to $5,000 a year.

speech.para: The committee concluded that cash based businesses suffer the most, struggling to fund more sophisticated accounting systems. The committee also found that the GST was a threat to small business's competitive edge because larger companies found it easier to absorb the administration costs. And to give a lie to one of the government's claims about the GST and the new tax package that it would deal with the black economy question, this parliamentary committee found that the cash economy was tipped to flourish as service industry businesses dodged the system.
