Here is a sensible amendment that has been misunderstood by the parliamentary secretary and obviously, by reading out the notes that have been prepared for him, by his advisers. They have an amount of time now available to them to realise that they have been in error in misunderstanding what this amendment actually proposes. They do not understand that it involves a discretion on the part of the tax commissioner—that it is not mandatory.

I see the parliamentary secretary has now picked up some notes. He is reading them. I will keep talking for another couple of minutes so that he will be able to continue reading his notes. I am sure that there is every chance that, having read those notes, having consulted with his advisers, he will realise the error of his ways and when he stands up to do a summing up, he will say, `Well, there you go! The shadow Treasurer has got it right. The Labor side has got it right. Here is a genuine attempt to improve': some roll-back, some administrative simplicity on the part of the government, that is, to make it even simpler by giving the Taxation Commissioner the discretion, not the mandatory requirement but the discretion. I see the parliamentary secretary is readying himself to make the announcement that: yes, they have made an error; it is fair enough. It will reflect very well on the parliamentary secretary to admit the error of his ways, to now understand what the amendment fully involves, that is, a discretion. It involves a further simplification of the GST—a simplification the business community is crying out for. Here is the opportunity for the parliamentary secretary to stand up and implement in this parliament a piece of good policy.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —There is a lot of bad publicity around politicians. Some are being accused of being paid by the word, and I suspect that accusation quite accurately could be applied to the honourable member for Rankin. I am pleased to reassure the honourable member that I did not misunderstand his initial contribution. In a situation where there had been no activity by the particular business, then the business activity statement would be very simple indeed. The government is absolutely determined to provide a continuing program of assistance to those required to complete business activity statements. In my summing up speech, I highlighted what some of this assistance is. The assistance is being provided by both the Taxation Office and the GST Start-Up Assistance Office. Over 4,000 workshops, field advisory visits and signpost offices are being made available to assist in completing a business activity statement. I mentioned these matters in my summing up, but it is clear that the honourable member for Rankin and others opposite were simply not listening. The message did not penetrate, did not get across to them. They must have been asleep, so for their benefit and for the benefit of other honourable members I thought I would just reiterate the fact that the government does have this very substantial series of assistance measures with respect to the business activity statement.

—I mentioned that we are currently in Business Activity Statement Help Week. That will run to 8 November in over 200 locations around Australia. During this week there is free practical advice and assistance to small businesses that have tried to fill in their first business activity statement but still have questions. There are 50,000 places by appointment.

speech.para: Those honourable members opposite ought not to misrepresent the government's determination to give all assistance necessary to businesses with respect to the completion of the business activity statement. The honourable member for Holt, who you, Mr Deputy Speaker, would notice has interjected out of his place, referred to the instruction booklet to complete the BAS. He said it was a large booklet. It is pretty obvious that the vast majority of businesses will only need a small proportion of the instruction booklet to complete the BAS. The member for Holt referred to the fact that some businesses will make mistakes on the BAS. I am pleased to assure the honourable member that businesses will not be subject to any late lodgment penalties where they have made a genuine attempt to comply. I have said that before. The government has said that before, over and over again, and yet honourable members from the Labor Party continue to come into the chamber and seek to misrepresent the actual situation. Businesses will be given the benefit of any doubt.

The honourable member for Rankin said that the amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is to allow the commissioner a discretion to deregister and is thus not complex. He suggests that the opposition amendment will simplify arrangements for those businesses which have made no supplies. As I said before, for those businesses the BAS obligations will be simple to comply with. Allowing retrospective amendments involves setting up expectations for businesses to deregister which cannot be met. Such a discretion would not be able to be exercised by the commissioner in many cases. Thus the government amendment, being prospective, allows businesses to prepare for a date from which GST and corresponding credit entitlements will not apply. So the opposition huffs and puffs and makes a lot of noise. The honourable member for Swan also again referred to strata title hotels and claimed that this was an anomaly. The Australian Taxation Office has issued a substantial ruling which explains in detail why a strata title unit cannot be a hotel as far as the individual owner is concerned. The issue concerns availability of input tax credits to the owners of such strata title units, as these units are akin to residential premises. The supply of them is input taxed, and to treat them differently would allow an unintended advantage to such investors over other landlords. Honourable members opposite have gone on and on, but the government is determined to make sure that the amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is defeated in this place, as it rightly should be.

talk.start.para: —Once again, the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration misses the point. The point is that the legislation needs to be changed. I do not think he understands that. He does not have a briefing note on it and he does not know what he is talking about. I mentioned earlier that this issue had been raised by Kareelya at the highest level of government, and the highest level of government usually sits in the chair opposite, I would have thought—the chair where the parliamentary secretary is now sitting. It is my understanding that the highest level of government has acknowledged—and I am assuming that it would be the person that normally sits in the chair currently occupied by the parliamentary secretary—that there is a problem, that it has acknowledged that there needed to be something done to deal with it, that it was wrong.

speech.para: I believe that Kareelya also raised it with the Assistant Commissioner of Taxation. The Assistant Commissioner of Taxation acknowledged that there was a problem with the act. It is an anomaly that needs to be changed. At all levels that they have spoken to, everybody has acknowledged that there is a problem that needs to be dealt with. When they have taken it up with one of the local members, the member for Kalgoorlie, he has assured them that he supports them and that he would do something for them. Unfortunately, no assistance has been forthcoming and nothing has been done. I also understand that the member representing the Bunbury and Busselton area acknowledged that there is a problem, but I am not sure to what degree he has taken that up either.

We have a problem here with the legislation. The government is dealing with amendments to make it fairer. Clearly here is an issue that needs to be resolved. The government needs to act. It needs to stop pussyfooting around, get on with doing the job of looking after the businesses that represent these sorts of interests and help to build the infrastructure that Australia needs.
Question put:

motion.para: That the amendment (Mr Crean's) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talker.name: Slipper, Peter, MP
Mr SLIPPER
talker.role: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Finance and Administration

talk.start.para: —by leave—I present the supplementary explanatory memorandum to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 8) 1999 and move government amendments 1 to 7 as circulated together:

quote.para: (1) Schedule 5, item 4, page 37 (lines 27 to 30), omit all the words (including the paragraphs) from and including “tax debt that is:”, substitute:
tax debt:
(a) that is:
(i) not a BAS amount (as defined in subsection 995-1(1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1997); and
(ii) due but not yet payable; or
(b) in respect of which the taxpayer has complied with an arrangement under section 255-15 to pay the debt by instalments; or
(c) in respect of which the Commissioner has agreed to defer recovery under section 255-5.
(2) Schedule 6, item 12, page 43 (after line 21), after subparagraph (ii), insert:
(iia) a member of, or a family member of a member of, any company referred to in subparagraph (i) or (ii) that is a company to which subsection (1A) applies; or
(3) Schedule 6, item 12, page 43 (after line 23), after subsection (1), insert:
(1A) This subsection applies to a company if:
(a) the company has only one member; or
(b) the company has more than one member, and:
(i) at least 2 of the members are beneficiaries of the trust in question (either directly, or indirectly through one or more interposed trusts); or
(ii) one of the members is such a beneficiary, and at least one other such beneficiary is a *family member of a different member of the company; or

(iii) none of the members is such a beneficiary, and those family members (of the members of the company) who are such beneficiaries are not all family members of the same member of the company and no other member.
(4) Schedule 6, item 20, page 45 (lines 16 to 20), omit the item, substitute:
Omit “those payments”, substitute “those payments (except to the extent that they are payments of excess to which section 78-18 applies)”.
(5) Schedule 6, item 21, page 45 (line 30), omit “acquisitions or importations”, substitute “*creditable acquisitions or *creditable importations”.
(6) Schedule 6, item 21, page 46 (line 12), omit “acquisitions and importations”, substitute “*creditable acquisitions and *creditable importations”.
(7) Schedule 6, item 21, page 46 (line 21), omit “acquisitions or importations”, substitute “*creditable acquisitions or *creditable importations”.

speech.para: Since this bill was introduced into parliament, further consideration by the Australian Taxation Office and consultation with industry has resulted in the need for minor technical changes to some provisions already existing in the bill. The first amendment is a concessional amendment relating to refunding business activity statement amounts. The law currently requires the Commissioner of Taxation to apply any credit or running balance account surplus against any liability of a taxpayer, including a tax debt that is due but not yet payable. While this offsetting of refunds against tax debts is necessary for the efficient collection of revenue, the government considered that offsetting should not always occur where amounts are not yet payable. Therefore an amendment was introduced in the bill to give the commissioner the discretion to be able to refund a net business activity statement credit rather than apply it to another tax debt that is due but not yet payable.

The government is amending this provision in order to allow the commissioner to refund amounts in cases where a tax debt is in dispute and finalisation of the matter is dependent on the decision of a court or tribunal. This will allow the commissioner the discretion not to offset a refund against a tax debt that is covered by an agreement with a taxpayer to defer recovery of a tax debt or to pay the tax debt by instalments.

The government is also amending the GST grouping provisions in the bill to allow a broader range of entities to group with a company. The existing amendment was introduced to ensure that, when company and non-company entities such as partnerships, trusts and individuals exist within one GST group, the companies must have some relationship to the non-company entities. However, the amendment is narrower in operation than the GST regulations that set out specific membership requirements for partnerships, trusts and individuals. Therefore, the government is amending the bill to better align the GST Act and GST regulations in this area. This will ensure that a company will also satisfy a relationship with a trust if the trust makes distributions to shareholders or family members of shareholders of companies that are members of the GST group.

The amendments in the bill relating to insurance were introduced to ensure that an insurer did not obtain a tax benefit by rearranging normal commercial practices in the payment of excesses. This is because there was an opportunity for an insurer to rearrange the payment of excess so that the insurer was entitled to an input tax credit for the amount of the excess, even though it had not paid it. The amendments contained in the bill were intended to provide for an increasing adjustment in such circumstances. An increasing adjustment increases the net amount owing to the Australian Taxation Office and therefore would claw back the tax benefit the insurer obtained. However, industry has raised concerns with the Australian Taxation Office that the amendments in the bill could apply more broadly than intended. In order to address these concerns, the government is amending the bill to ensure that the increasing adjustment applies only where the insurer was entitled to an input tax credit for an acquisition or importation made directly for the purpose of settling the claim. A corresponding amendment is also required to ensure that the amount of excess taken into account in determining the insurer's decreasing adjustment on an insurance settlement is reduced only to the extent that the insurer has an increasing adjustment on the excess. Full details of the amendments in the bill are contained in the supplementary explanatory memorandum. I commend the amendments to the House.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

subdebate.1.para: Bill (on motion by Mr Slipper)—by leave—read a third time.
Debate resumed from 12 April, on motion by Mr Williams:

motion.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —This debate has been a long time coming. The Privacy Amendment (Private Sector) Bill 2000 is an important bill from the point of view both of citizens' rights and of the development of future economic activity and, importantly, economic activity through electronic means and, in this day and age, over the Internet. I suppose we are seeing two different philosophies here before the House: that advocated by the government, which is essentially one of trying to develop a culture of privacy in the private sector, and one which the opposition will be advocating. That is one where there is some enforcement, some actual grunt, in the legislation to enforce citizens' rights and indeed to give the business community generally confidence that privacy is actually an enforceable right and protected in transactions. Our criticism of the government's approach is that, while they have provided a car by setting out some national privacy principles with which we essentially agree and indeed which in many ways have been utilised in the public sector through the Privacy Act, they have not provided an engine, so these principles are not really being driven anywhere. They exist and, yes, people can point to them as being aspirations, but we are getting into virtually non-existent or at best extremely weak enforcement regimes. The Attorney-General himself says that this is light touch legislation. We say it is worse than that: it is feather touch. I will point to the Attorney's statement on 18 October this year when he referred to a survey of business practices that intruded into privacy. Speaking of this government's intention, he put it this way:

quote.para: It is clear that a cultural change is required to ensure that the protection of privacy is part of ... business practice. To help encourage this change, the Government has adopted a light touch, co-regulatory approach to privacy in the private sector.

speech.para: The Attorney refers to encouraging a cultural change through a light touch coregulatory approach. But again we say that much more grunt is needed in the legislation to give it some purpose, and our amendments will be intended, in goodwill, to achieve that. I might add that there have been two excellent inquiries in this area, by the House and by the Senate, and I understand a further Senate report will be handed down on Wednesday, which may well have some additional contribution to make to the debate.

As all Australians would be aware, the growth of electronic commerce over the Internet has been astounding. Even if people are not buying products through the Internet, they are perhaps using it to do their banking or at least inquire as to what their banking records show. We have seen recently a tremendous boom in dot.com companies on the stock market both in Australia and overseas. There was a tremendous increase in the value of their stocks. Equally, however, we saw a rapid decline as confidence in those dot.com companies burst. One of the reasons why the value of those shares toppled so dramatically was that these dot.com companies were developing value on the basis of the number of hits on a particular ad or a particular web site. Those hits were being represented by the dotcom companies as anticipated marketing potential. But it has been revealed that the marketing potential from those hits has not eventuated: the hits have not coincided with people purchasing goods through the advertisements as displayed on the web sites or on the particular screens that come up. All of the evidence indicates that a significant, if not the most significant, reason why purchases have not followed from the hits is the concerns that people—not only Australians but those around the world—have about their privacy.

An increasing number of members would know what happens when you enter into a transaction on the Internet. A dialogue box will come up and it will ask you your name and address, which is of course required if you are purchasing a product and it is being mailed to you. But more often than not there will be some sort of incentive plan attached to it, so it will ask you about other issues, such as areas of interest and perhaps even community groups that you may belong to or chat clubs or news groups that you may be interested in, which clearly goes beyond the purpose, the particular purchase or transaction. So we are seeing not only information directly being obtained for the purchase but also a whole range of ancillary information which will go into building a profile of the particular customer.

Not only is that occurring with respect to specific transactions but through the use of the Internet—the mechanisms are substantially beyond my expertise—we have seen the use of cookies and even Internet bugs, as I understand it, which feed back information to companies which have placed these cookies regarding your particular browsing over the Internet. Someone has described the use of these bugs, depending on the nature of the cookie, as branding a bar code—such as the one you see when you buy goods from a shopping centre—on your forehead, if you like, so that every time you browse a particular web site it is like walking through the door of a shop and the bar code activates that this particular person has been in the shop and at least had a look around. Then the person will move on, look at another site and walk into another shop, and that will be identified. Perhaps a person's name, address and other details will not be included, but when the person makes a transaction that trail is then recorded and linked to that person. So, very quickly, this information can come together and develop a profile on the person.

This is not future technology; this is happening now. Many people are apprehensive regarding their privacy rights on the Internet without knowing why they have these apprehensions—they just have them. What is needed is legislation not only to address rights but also to assure Australians that their rights are being protected. Not only is this information used for marketing purposes where companies figure from someone's profile the sort of things they have looked at—whether it is boats, surfing products, whatever it might be—and fire particular ads directed at that sort of area, but increasingly evidence is being shown that businesses are using the information to downgrade the ranking of a customer so that they are identified as someone who is not particularly desirable and, indeed, it would probably be better for the overall profitability of the business if they were to go elsewhere—actually putting them on a lower key priority in terms of a response time or what products or services are offered to them. The use of this information not only can be constructive but also can be very destructive. These are not potential concerns but very real concerns in the community. Indeed, here are some figures to substantiate it from Roy Morgan Research:

quote.para: The majority of Australians (56%) are worried about invasion of privacy issues created by new information technologies ... More than one-in-six Australians (18%) said they `strongly agree' notwithstanding the statement, `I'm worried about the invasion of privacy through new technology', with a further 38% saying they `agree' with the statement.

speech.para: That is certainly a significant figure. Recently, the Attorney-General released figures regarding concerns voiced by Australians and raised with the Privacy Commissioner. The Attorney-General noted:

quote.para: The Commissioner's web site averaged 4000 hits a month last financial year—up from previous year's average of 25000 per month.
During 1999/2000, the Hotline received 9454 calls, 474 more than the previous year.

speech.para: Interestingly, the Attorney notes that most of those complaints related to the private sector, not to government. This is an increasing trend now. Previously, it was governments that had the capacity to be so intrusive into the lives of ordinary Australians with the information they recovered but, with outsourcing and with these new technologies, that power is very much shifting to the private sector. The private sector, as the Attorney has indicated, just has not had that culture of privacy protection. That is shown very much by a recent survey by Arthur Andersen. There are five points that are certainly worth noting to realise the significance of the invasion of privacy and how Australians' concerns are justified. The summary of the survey showed:

quote.para: Although 72% of the sites surveyed—

speech.para: that is, involved in electronic commerce—

quote.para: collected personal information, only 51% had a published privacy policy and only 28% of those sites notify their users about the specific personal information that is collected.

speech.para: The second point is:

quote.para: 71% of the web sites with a stated privacy policy say that personal identifying information may be disclosed to third parties but one in three of those sites do not offer users a choice with respect to that disclosure.

speech.para: That is a significant finding. The third point is:

quote.para: 43% of the sites that collected personal information did so without the user actively providing that information.

speech.para: This is through cookies and bugs and the like. The fourth point is:

quote.para: 15% of web sites without a statement about third party disclosures attempted to place third parties cookies (sent from ad servers).

speech.para: This is placing, if you like, the spies or fifth columnists on your particular computer system. The final point is:

quote.para: Only 14% of the sites surveyed say that they give users the opportunity to have at least some personal information about them deleted from web site records.

speech.para: These figures indicate what is happening in industry today, and they are significant figures because it is very likely that those businesses, if they are of substance in their marketing, will be a party to a voluntary privacy code. These figures are being revealed in an atmosphere where there is, in many areas, self-regulation. We have to ask, `Is self-regulation good enough?' I think those figures give sufficient concern to say, `Self-regulation is not good enough and something more needs to be done about it.

To see the government's reluctance to move a step further, you have only to look at the history of this legislation in the parliament. While it is customary for a member of the opposition to stand here and criticise backflips of the government, I do so on this occasion to demonstrate the reason behind the weakness in the government's approach. The Liberal Party had as its policy before the 1996 election the development of privacy legislation. But, in March 1997, the government announced a withdrawal from that position and said that it favoured self-regulation rather than legislation in the area. There is no doubt that that was primarily as a result of pressure from the Prime Minister. The government was quite happy to go along with that except for the fact that the states—conservative and Labor states—said, `This is going to cause us real problems because, if we don't have privacy legislation, there is a significant risk of trade with other countries being impeded.' In particular, the European Union said, `Unless you have an acceptable privacy framework, we aren't going to trade with you, because the information which we convey in the course of that trade could be released through your system. In other words, before we embark on trade in the electronic environment with you, we need to be satisfied that your privacy standards are acceptable.'

The various state governments—indeed, Victoria was quite advanced in the development of its regime—put forward their own legislation. Industry then said, `Hold on, we're in one nation but we're looking at the prospect of having six or seven different privacy systems.' That would have been totally unacceptable to a national economy, the activity in which goes beyond state boundaries and indeed beyond national boundaries. It was only then that the government came in and said, `Yes, there is a need for national privacy regulation.' But all the way we can see in their reasoning a throwback to the March 1997 withdrawal from the need for legislation. Hence, what we are looking at today is very weak—not light touch legislation but feather touch legislation, as advocated by the government. We in the opposition say that the fundamental reasoning with which the government has come into this area has been too timid and, for that reason, is flawed.

However, on the other side, we acknowledge that some regulation is better than no regulation, so our approach is not to throw the baby out with the bathwater but to make some constructive suggestions. One of our primary concerns about the legislation is that important privacy principles relating to access and correction, and the use and disclosure of information, do not apply to existing databases. So, in many ways, the horse has already bolted, and the horse has bolted with the private information of Australian citizens riding on it. We saw recently the giant Axiom database—Axiom being a business subsidiary of a larger American company—with the information of some 15 million Australians apparently on it, information which had been obtained from merging information from all types of sources—from the ninemsn web site, from Ticketek and from other sources. They already exist in Australia. If this legislation goes through unamended, Australians have absolutely no prospect of accessing and correcting that information. That is the second point—there is not only the misuse of the information but the consumer's access to it.

The second area we have concerns about is that the Privacy Commissioner has effectively been left out in the cold in terms of regulating these industry codes. That is unacceptable because it is going to result in a whole range of diverse interpretations being made throughout Australia according to the particular privacy adjudicator under separate and discrete privacy codes. They will exist as silos all around the country, and the Privacy Commissioner will not have the right to step into the shoes of those adjudicators and set a common framework. The Privacy Commissioner's powers in respect of those private sector codes will be minimal indeed. The Privacy Commissioner at best will have the power to review their annual reports and, if he considers anything awry, to determine whether not they will be reregistered. But he will not have, for instance, the power to inspect documents, the power to interview witnesses or the power to conduct a privacy audit of these private sector codes, and we say that that is inadequate.

We say that the Privacy Commissioner's powers are inadequate not only in terms of investigation but also in terms of his inability to impose a penalty. This is significant. While the Privacy Commissioner does have the power to recommend compensation in respect of a privacy breach, he does not have the power to order a penalty. By way of an example, if it were disclosed that I subscribe to Tracks Surfing Magazine, that may or may not affect my reputation in the eyes of some citizens. If I complained about it, the Privacy Commissioner might say, `It shouldn't have been disclosed; I'm prepared to order some compensation. I'll give you a token monetary amount.' But the disclosure of my subscription may have been part of an overall scheme, an overall assault, to tap into a particular publisher's web site, and the intrusion into the privacy of citizens generally may have been so extensive that a penalty is warranted. However, the legislation does not provide that sort of opportunity.

Generally, I think Australians see that, if there is going to be any teeth in the law covering consumer protection, you need to have an active regulator. Look at the powers of the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission in the area of consumer protection. That is very much an example of you needing teeth before a culture of consumer protection can develop. The point I am making is that, to be fair dinkum about protecting Australians' rights, you need effective regulation.
Debate interrupted.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I propose the question:

motion.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —The question of Reserve recruitment in this country has certainly been in the forefront of concerns of people in support committees around the country. Recently, the crisis in recruitment levels forced the government to actually look at employer subsidies. But that, of course, will not solve the fundamental problem.

speech.para: Tonight I want to talk about the Department of Defence annual report for 1999-2000. It was tabled last week, and it revealed that Defence had spent a massive $34.8 million of taxpayers' money last financial year on advertising and market research. Of that figure, $32.8 million was spent by the Defence Personnel Executive mainly on recruitment campaigns and $9.7 million was allocated solely towards the recruitment of officers for ADFA. One has to question whether this sort of expenditure is really being well spent under the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence. You would expect a pretty impressive recruitment outcome with the devotion of this kind of money from taxpayers. Instead, we read elsewhere in the report that Defence met only 74 per cent of its recruitment targets for the permanent forces and an embarrassing 31 per cent for the reserves—and that is not going to be fixed up by employer subsidies, quite frankly. By service, the Army and RAAF met 83 per cent of their recruitment targets for full-time personnel, while the Navy managed a mere 57 per cent of its positions. As the annual report notes on page 79:

quote.para: Failure to meet recruiting targets, combined with separations, is creating increasing workforce gaps within the Services. Navy is most affected with vacancies of almost 2,000 against requirements, resulting in higher workloads to be shared among its people.

speech.para: This is at a time when this government rabbits on every second day of the week about the way in which we are going to become more and more dependent on the reserves. They say that personnel costs mean that we essentially cannot afford full-time personnel to undertake these roles and we are going to depend more on reserves. While that is happening we have this atrocious performance managed by the minister, who just does not understand that there is more to this task than a bit of backslapping at RSL conferences and wearing a few uniforms around the place. He has to actually get down and do something about the recruitment levels.

The report reveals that the government's procrastination over the measures to rebuild the Army Reserve exacerbated the so-called hollowness that clearly afflicts most Reserve units. In the 12 months from June 1999, the number of active Army reservists actually shrank by a massive 18 per cent from just under 22,000 to a little under 18,000—and the government continues to insist that the Army Reserve will be required to shoulder a great share of our national defence effort. In a massive understatement the Defence annual report—the government's own document—comments that:

quote.para: Of concern was poor Army General Reserve enlistments, which achieved only 33% of the target.

speech.para: To appreciate the seriousness of the recruitment position of the Army Reserve, I would like to refer to data I have obtained for the eight years commencing in July 1992. These figures come from my analysis of previous Defence annual reports. In the six years to June 1998, the Army Reserve recruited an average of 4,800 new personnel a year. During that period the year-by-year variation was fairly small—ranging from about 4,300 to just fewer than 5,800. In contrast, under the current administration of this country, over the last two years we have seen the worst recruiting outcomes in living memory. In 1998-99, the number of recruits plummeted to 2,281 and in 1999-2000 it fell even further to 1,566.

This worrying outcome would be bad enough if it was the first indication of any sort of problem with the reserves. Typical of what is going on with the $32 million they are spending around the place, the 11th/28th Battalion recently conducted an exercise in Western Australia. They had 100 people turn up and express interest. The exercise was called `Try before you buy' and people could see what the reserves was like. They obtained the interest of 100 people, but these people were not told beforehand that only five people were able to go on the course. So they actually spent this taxpayer money on having this day and seeing people's interest—actually, for once, managing to get a few people there; it is very rare these days—and then none of those people were told until afterwards that there were only five possible training positions interstate.

As I say, the annual report—the government's own wording—indicates an alarming decline in recruitment in this country at a time when Timor has indicated, more than ever, the need to depend upon reserves. We just cannot financially afford to do it any other way, and the continued downturn in reserve recruitment is quite alarming.

subdebateinfo.title: Robertson Electorate: Spencer Community Centenary Celebrations

talk.start.para: —Earlier today during 90-second statements I mentioned the Spencer Public School and their centenary celebrations. Obviously I did not have long enough to really do justice to the celebrations that I attended last Saturday, 4 November, and I thought I would take the opportunity this evening to elaborate a little on the Spencer school and the history of that area of the Hawkesbury River.

speech.para: The Hawkesbury River, of course, was a very important part of the early days of Sydney and, in fact, was the lifeblood of the small colony of Sydney. Education of children was quite difficult in those days because of the transport problems. Spencer school was established in 1900. I have a document in front of me that was put together by the Headmaster of Spencer school, Mr Paul Miller. It is a very detailed document of the history of Spencer school from 1900 through to 2000. The school has always been a fairly small school. At one stage they had about 42 students, which was the largest number of pupils at that school. At the moment they have only 10 students there. People might say that it is uneconomic to have a school of that size. If that school was not there, those students would have to travel approximately three hours per day to get to the next closest public school—and we are talking about primary school, so we are talking about children from five years through to 12 years—and it would not be practical.

In my electorate there are five communities that have water access only; they do not have road access to their communities. Many of the children who live in that area commute by boat to the Spencer school or to Mooney Mooney school in my own town of Mooney Mooney. It is a fairly unique electorate, along with that of my parliamentary colleague, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Philip Ruddock. Ours are probably the only electorates in New South Wales that have so many communities which are accessible only by boat. The education of these children is very important, and schools such as Spencer, Mooney Mooney and Brooklyn play a very important part in the education of these children.

These schools are fine examples of government school education in New South Wales. There has obviously been a debate about education funding and the commitment that the government has to government and non-government schools in New South Wales, and I am very proud to say that the education level of all the schools in my electorate of Robertson is excellent. It is the dedication of the teachers in both the government and non-government schools that enables the standard of education to be as high as it is in New South Wales, and in particular in my electorate of Robertson.

I would like to congratulate the principal of Spencer Public School, Mr Paul Miller, for the work that he does with the school and for the work that he does in linking the school to the community. I would also like to congratulate the P&C president, Mrs Donna Thompson, for the work she did in organising the celebrations on Saturday, and all the P&C and the community of Spencer who rallied behind the celebrations on Saturday, including the local volunteer bushfire brigade and many other volunteers. Whilst the community is small and the school is a very small school, they all rallied. I would estimate that there was a crowd of more than 200 people at the celebrations. The school district inspector, Mr Bill Lowe, also attended the celebrations, along with the state member for Peats, Ms Marie Andrews. It was a very significant day, and it was interesting to watch the number of people who commuted up the river from communities such as Bar Point, Greenman's Valley, Milsons Passage and Milson Island, who brought their children up by tinnies, as we call them—small aluminium boats—to make sure that they were part of the celebration days for the Spencer Public School.

Spencer Public School has a long and proud history, and I am sure that it has a very secure future and that it will continue to educate our river kids in the best possible way. We will certainly ensure that they have a very bright and wonderful future, with a great education system in schools such as Spencer.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Small Business

talk.start.para: —Friday of this week is the last working day small businesses will have to submit their first business activity statement. We have all seen the advertisements on TV—`The new tax system: give it a go'—but there is no real choice for small business people. They have to face up to the paperwork or face the consequences, which are severe. The Taxation Office said they will go easy on first-time errors, but that does not lessen the pressure or the amount of work required of small business people. They still have to go through all the processes to prepare their first business activity statement.

speech.para: Over the last few months, I conducted a survey of all businesses in my electorate, asking for feedback on the initial effects of the GST. The first question in the survey was: `What has been the impact of the GST on your business?' Of those who replied, 61 per cent said that the GST had had a negative impact on their businesses. The next question was: `Did the implementation of the GST in your business increase your costs?' 75 per cent said yes. The third question was: `In terms of one-off costs, how much would you estimate it has cost your business to implement the GST?' 43 per cent said it had cost them between $1,000 and $5,000—a one-off cost which is significant for small businesses. The next question was: `In terms of ongoing costs, how much would you estimate it will cost your business to comply with the GST?' 66 per cent thought it would cost between $1,000 and $10,000, and this was an increase on their earlier costs. The last question was: `Has your business declined due to the GST?' 43 per cent answered yes. There were not many surprises in the results. The vast majority of the small business people who replied felt that their businesses had suffered as a result of the introduction of the GST. 43 per cent said that their business had declined as a result of the GST.

One woman who runs an agistment business in Waroona has been trapped by the government's decision not to allow businesses to withdraw from the system before 1 July of next year. She believes that if they cannot withdraw they are going to have to close their business and put people out of work. The other result that she found from the introduction of the GST was that, while she offered agistment for a number of overseas owners of horses, those owners had decided to take their horses out of Australia much earlier than they normally would have because of the increase in costs she had had to add. So the whole racing industry was suffering as a result.

The government seems to struggle to understand that the majority of small businesses employ small numbers of people, and it means that the vast amount of paperwork required needs to be added onto the owner's workload. The only alternative to the owner struggling to complete the paperwork is to pass it on to the accountant, thus dramatically increasing the cost of having an accountant—from a consultation once a year to needing the accountant's services four times a year. In a number of small communities in my electorate, a number of businesses made the decision to close on 30 June rather than facing the impact of the GST.

talk.start.para: —How many?

—Quite a few. A few months after, another five businesses in Waroona, which is a very small community, had closed. Five may not sound like a lot, but if you live in a community of 1,000 households it is a large number of businesses. They may have offered only part-time employment, but it was incredibly important to those who lived there. You can be dismissive of small numbers, but try living in the town and try living with the consequences.

speech.para: Small businesses already suffer as a consequence of the government's policies. This is an increased burden and it is an unfair burden. Many small businesses are trapped in the system. They have no choice. It is no comfort to be told to give it a gobut of course most of them probably have not seen the advertisement because they are too busy doing the paperwork. Many have spent their lives struggling to build up their businesses, believing it was their superannuation. Instead, they can see their businesses failing in front of their eyes. It does not matter whether it is my survey of small business in the Canning electorate or the Morgan and Banks survey or a survey from speaking to small business owners, we all know that the GST is hurting small businesses. It is unfair of the government to say, `Give it a go,' when the odds are stacked against a number of businesses surviving. The government owes it to the business community to give them a fighting chance.

talk.start.para: —You can sneer, but try living it. You will pay the price at the next election.

—I rise this evening to firstly draw the House's attention to a problem which is not unique to my area but is one which nonetheless is a source of serious concern and also to pay tribute to Councillor Tony Hall, who until recently was the Mayor of Ku-Ring-Gai Municipal Council. Councillor Hall led an initiative which recently brought together principals from secondary schools in the electorate of Bradfield, State Rail authorities, local police and those who have an interest in trying to control not only drug peddling but also other forms of antisocial behaviour by some elements in and around our train stations.

speech.para: Drugs have always been with us. Human beings, and young people in particular, seem imbued with a desire to find altered consciousness. But, at the moment, we live in a society where there is an unprecedented level of drug use and indeed various forms of self-destructive behaviour by young people. Up and down the North Shore line, on the North Shore of Sydney, our train stations are increasingly becoming places at which young people congregate and where drugs are peddled by not only some people from the south-west of Sydney but also some locals. There are a number of reasons why this is occurring. Most importantly, given that many young people begin their drug-taking careers in this sort of environment, we as a caring society have obligations to do something about it.

There are a number of issues that contribute to this situation. The first is that the reduced presence of authority figures on railway stations and platforms has led young people to become increasingly brazen in their misbehaviours on the train platforms. One unintended consequence of removing train station masters and replacing them with either ticketing machines or ticketing officers is that young people are congregrating without any kind of adult supervision on train station platforms. There is at the moment little if any policing of railway passes. Many young people, particularly in my electorate, are not travelling directly from school to home or vice versa, and they are being encouraged to by parents who, whilst providing for the material possessions they feel their children need, unfortunately have left them in a position of emotional abandonment.

We are also in a ludicrous situation where, if a schoolchild is not travelling according to the requirements of the rail pass, the State Rail Authority and the Transit Police are not able to inform the school or the parents. So that means that these kids leave school at 3.15 p.m. and arrive home at 6 p.m—before their parents, I might add. The parents have little if any idea of where their children have been or what they have been doing. In some instances where police have asked these kids to move on, the police have subsequently been phoned by parents who have abused the police for actually moving their kids on, the parents being of the view that it is quite acceptable, if not desirable, for their kids to hang around for a couple of hours after school in places like the Chatswood or Pymble interchanges.

The second point is that Mr Carr, the New South Wales Premier, would be well advised to spend a little less time behaving like Nero and to put on a pair of jeans, a T-shirt and a baseball hat, to get on a train at about 9 o'clock at night and travel around Sydney for a couple of hours to get a taste of what the real world is like. You need to visit a train station in Sydney any time after 9 o'clock or 10 o'clock at night in just about any part of Sydney to get a small glimpse of the problems we face in our railway stations, where a significant number of young people congregate, where alcohol is being consumed excessively and where drugs are certainly being traded.

The other thing that is most important is that the program of camera surveillance installation in New South Wales train stations needs to be urgently expedited. Also, local governments as well as state governments ought to consider employing security guards to supervise train platforms and bus interchanges at key hours of the day. If that means higher taxes and rates, I believe most of the people I represent would be prepared to pay them. Finally, but not least, parents need to understand that they have obligations and responsibilities to their children which extend beyond providing them with material resources. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —All of us in this place have schools visit Canberra from our electorate. They come here for a variety of reasons, but all schools make a real effort to visit Parliament House while they are in the nation's capital. I was delighted today to host two schools from my electorate: 60 students from St Michael's Collegiate and 17 students from the small school of Glen Huon Primary on their visit to Canberra. The subsidy which allows schools from the more remote regions to lessen the costs to students and their families of visiting Canberra is greatly appreciated by parents and schools. I know that there are moves to increase the amount in 2001 during our centenary year so that even more schoolchildren will experience just what takes place in this building.

speech.para: All students who visit Parliament House visit the PEO, the Parliamentary Education Office, and participate in a range of role-play sessions that are designed to give students the opportunity to gain some insight into the workings of the parliamentary system. All of us in this place have sat in on those sessions and watched with real interest as these young people attempt to understand why we do what we do. We watch the teachers from the PEO take classes through the daily opening of the House and through the basics of the introduction of a bill and the second reading proceedings.

As a former teacher, I have always been impressed with the dedication and professionalism of the staff of the PEO. They encourage the children, either primary or secondary students, to have a go and to get a feel for what their elected members and senators do in their respective chambers. I have been privileged to serve on the advisory committee to the PEO for the last six years. One of the things that really impressed me about the PEO, apart from the fantastic work they do here in Canberra, is the outreach service they provide to teachers in distant parts of Australia. I really valued their visits to Tasmania and have been privileged to welcome teachers to the sessions held in the Tasmanian parliament in Hobart. I know for a fact that teachers in my state really value the sessions that the PEO runs with them and are very appreciative of their guidance and support.

Today is a sad day for the PEO and the House. Today is the last day for two of the shining stars in the PEO stable of superb teachers. Judy Gauld and Jennet Cole-Adams are leaving after long and meritorious service to take up staff positions at the Museum of Australia. Judy and Jennet are the very best of teachers. They have a love of learning and their obvious enthusiasm for their job is evidenced by the willingness of all students to participate in the various role-playing exercises they present for young students. I guess it is time for them to move on to pastures new and to assist in setting up the latest addition to Canberra's highlights, the Museum of Australia. I can assure you, Mr Speaker, the museum's gain is certainly our loss. I trust that both Judy and Jennet will have a wonderful new life just down the road from us, and I know that we will all miss them from in our midst. Their wonderful contribution to Parliament House will long be remembered not only by their work colleagues and the members in this place but also, more importantly, by the thousands of children who have passed through their hands in the countless PEO sessions they have conducted over the last eight years. It was a great privilege to have met you both and to have developed a real friendship in the time that I have been in this place. I can assure you that everyone in this House who has come into contact with them wishes them all the best for the future.

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Franklin for his sentiments and say that I am sure all members of the House would want to be identified with what he has just said with reference to Parliament House staff.

subdebateinfo.title: Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Legislation

talk.start.para: —I would like to take the opportunity this evening to speak on the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1999, as I did not have the opportunity during the last parliamentary sittings to do so. I would like to commend the Attorney-General, the Hon. Daryl Williams, the Deputy Prime Minister, the Hon. John Anderson, and, of course, the Prime Minister, the Hon. John Howard, for their work in this area. I would also like to commend the member for Dawson, De-Anne Kelly, for her role, which, if time allows, I will outline later. These amendments have removed those provisions in theClassification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1999 that relate to the proposal to abolish the X classification and create a new classification entitled non-violent erotica, or NVE. This follows the government's decision to retain the X classification for sexually explicit videos but with, I am delighted to say, a more restricted content. These restrictions include excluding from such films any form of violence whatsoever, certain fetishes, sexually aggressive language and the portrayal of people over the age of 18 as minors.

speech.para: These additional restrictions are now reflected in amendments to the National Classification Code and the Classification Guidelines agreed to by the Commonwealth and state and territory censorship ministers, which took effect on 18 September 2000. The amendments will also make an unrelated consequential amendment to section 53 of the Classification (Publications, Films and Computer Games) Act 1995 to authorise the Director of the Classification Board to exercise expanded powers under state and Northern Territory laws to call in certain publications, films and computer games for classification, reclassification or review of a classification decision, as the case requires. The amendment of state and territory legislation will be required to complement the expanded call-in powers to similar effect to be conferred on the director under the bill in relation to material published or likely to be published in the Australian Capital Territory.

I have said publicly on many occasions that if adults want to watch certain movies, that is their prerogative. However, I have also said: let's call a spade a spade—hard-core pornography is hard-core pornography. I commend the Attorney-General, the Hon. Daryl Williams, for introducing the amendment bill in an effort to inject responsible leadership and direction into this debate and to provide peace of mind for Australian families. I add that the intimidatory tactics used by the Eros Foundation in its campaign for the creation of a new classification entitled non-violent erotica should be deplored on both sides of the political fence. I have been the target of a campaign by the Eros Foundation in which I have been slammed in the media just for taking a stand in the interests of families and minors in our community.

The Eros Foundation has publicly stated that it will campaign for opposition candidates at the next election, distributing thousands of how-to-vote cards advising their customers and the community to vote against me. As a coalition member of parliament, I think it is rather sad that, according to the Eros Foundation, I will be targeted at the next federal election for standing for these family values. If I suffer the consequences of fighting to stop a bill that would allow my children and those within my electorate ready access to hard-core films, so be it. In this scenario, a vote for my opponent is an endorsement for increased availability for explicit hard-core pornography. I have long fought against inappropriate films becoming more readily available and accessible to minors. That is why I so vehemently opposed the film Lolita, with its depiction of a middle-aged man's exploitation and abuse of a 12-year-old child in the name of entertainment. But the fact that the Eros Foundation had the gall to actively target me for my beliefs is, I think, a sad indictment of that organisation. Once again, I take this opportunity to commend the bill to the House and congratulate Daryl Williams on his work in this area.

motion.para: That this House:
(1) notes that stroke is the second highest cause of death in Australia;
(2) notes that there has been a slowing down of the decline in stroke death rates in recent years;
(3) notes that the number of people dying from stroke and those surviving with a permanent disability is likely to increase in the future;

(6) notes that while more women are affected by stroke, the proportion of men who suffer a stroke is 30 per cent higher than for women, and that for people aged 25-64, those from the lowest socio-economic group are twice as likely to die from stroke as those in the highest socioeconomic group with indigenous death rates from stroke in the same age group being eight times the rate in the rest of the population; and

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 30 September 1999:

quote.para: (1) Did the Coalition promise not to introduce new taxes or increase existing taxes during the 1996 election.
(2) What tax rates did the Government increase and what new taxes did it introduce between the 1996 and 1998 Federal elections.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Coalition policy for the 1996 election was not to introduce new taxes or increase existing taxes as a contrast to the Keating Labor Government which promised prior to the 1993 election not to increase taxes, and then after that election:-
- Increased wholesale sales tax rates from 10%, 20% and 30% to 12%, 22% and 32%;

(2) None

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 11 May 2000:

quote.para: (1) Does the Minister's Department administer any Commonwealth funded programs for which community organisations, businesses or individuals can apply for funding in Tasmania; if so, what are the programs.

(2) Does the Minister's Department advertise these funding opportunities; if so, (a) what print media outlets have been used for the advertising of each of these programs and (b) were these paid advertisements.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Minister for the Arts and the Centenary of Federation

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes, the Department of Communications, Information Technology and the Arts does administer Commonwealth funded programs through which community organisations, businesses or individuals can apply for funding in Tasmania.
The programs are:

answer.para: · Playing Australia, the national performing arts touring program;
· Contemporary Music Touring Program, which funds bands to undertake national tours;
· Visions of Australia, the national exhibitions touring program;
· Festivals Australia, which funds cultural activities at regional and community festivals;

quote.para: During the last three years, organisations based in Tasmania have been successful in obtaining funding from the Playing, Visions and Festivals programs.

answer.para: · Television Fund, through which eligible community organisations can apply for funding under two components of the Television Fund:-

quote.para: (i) Under the Television Black Spots Program community groups or local government authorities can apply for funding to retransmit ABC, SBS and commercial television services in black spot areas of poor or non-existent television reception.
(ii) The Remote Commercial Subsidy Program is open to existing self-help retransmission groups in remote broadcast areas seeking to rebroadcast a second remote commercial television service.

answer.para: · Community Broadcasting,

quote.para: In 2000-01, the Commonwealth will provide $5.407m to assist community broadcasting. These funds are allocated to the Community Broadcasting Foundation Ltd (CBF) in accordance with the terms of an annual grant agreement administered by the Department. The CBF is an independent company established by the community broadcasting sector to allocate funding assistance to individual stations and peak bodies. There are now over 190 community stations throughout Australia that are eligible to apply to the CBF for grants.

Specific proportions of the annual grant are directed to community broadcasting in general and to sub-sectors with special needs: ethnic broadcasting, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander broadcasting and broadcasting for the print handicapped.

answer.para: · Networking the Nation

quote.para: Networking the Nation is a Commonwealth grants program providing over $400 million in funding to not-for-profit organisations to support activities and projects designed to address a range of telecommunications needs in regional, rural and remote Australia.
The different parts of the program consist of the:

- General Fund. Established in 1997 following the sale of the first third of Telstra. This is the original and main part of the program. Under this part of the program $250 million was allocated to the States and Territories over a five-year period commencing in 1997. Tasmania received $58 million.
- mote and Isolated Island Communities. This part of the Fund is providing $20 million to address the particular telecommunications needs of remote and isolated island communities.

- proved Internet Access. This part of the program is providing $36 million to ensure that all Australians have untimed local call Internet access, or at least the equivalent where traditional dial-up access is not feasible.

- Building Additional Rural Networks (BARN).This part of the program is providing $70 million to support the development of new networks and new network services and products, using innovation and leading edge technologies. $10 million is being provided to each State, with a further $10 million to be divided between the Territories.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 15 August 2000:

quote.para: (1) With regard to Patricks dispute with the Maritime Union of Australia, is he able to say whether the Prime Minister told the 1998 New South Wales Liberal State Conference that Australia's export future was at stake.
(2) What was the cost of a dry container on the (a) Melbourne-Singapore, (b) Melbourne-Hong Kong, (c) Melbourne-Bangkok and (d) Melbourne-Seoul runs (i) prior to the dispute and (ii) in October 1999.
(3) What was the cost of dry container on the routes referred to in part (2) in August 2000.

(4) Has the peak Australian shippers association said that despite the Government's professed concerns at export costs that Australian exports had not had a cent in benefits from increased stevedoring efficiency.
(5) In the period since January 1998 to July 2000, has Lang Corporation's share price risen from $1.16 to $9.09.
(6) During the period referred to in part (5), what benefits have accrued to Australian importers or exporters as the result of drops in the cost of stevedoring.

(7) Did he meet Lord Sterling, Chairman of P&O, when he was in London for the Centenary of Federation celebrations; if so, did he raise with Lord Sterling the possibility of passing on some of the cost savings of waterfront reform to Australian importers and exporters; if no, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Yes. The Prime Minister in a speech to the New South Wales division of the Liberal Party on 3 April 1998 stated:

“It will be important that you continue to give us, and those involved in these events, your wholehearted support because Australia's export income future is at stake. The potential jobs of thousands of Australians are involved and the economic reputation and the reliability of this country as seen by the rest of the world is very much involved.”

(2) and (3) Actual freight rate levels in liner shipping are a commercial in confidence matter, and can vary between individual shipping lines and their clients, depending on factors such as the nature, value and volume of the cargo, and the regularity of shipments.

However, information in the Productivity Commission's report on International Liner Cargo Shipping (15 September 1999) indicated that the general trend in freight rates for Australian exports had been downward in the past decade. In a number of cases rates were reported to have fallen to levels that were commercially unsustainable in the long term. For example, information from the liner shipping industry indicates that between 1995 and 1999 export freight rates fell in real terms by about 10% in the European trade, by about 13% in the North American trade, by about 28% in the North Asia trade, and by about 50% in the South East Asia trade.

These decreases in freight rates were largely due an oversupply of shipping. The larger falls in the Asian trades reflect the added factor of the Asian economic crisis. Since mid 1999 there has been a recovery in freight rates, but in general these are reported to be still below the 1995 levels in real terms.

Stevedoring charges make up only a minor proportion of the freight rates paid by export shippers. On 27 August 1999 in response to a question from Senator O'Brien of the Senate's Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee as to whether there has been an overall increase or decrease in stevedoring charges since the beginning of 1998,
Patrick Stevedores CEO Mr Chris Corrigan stated: `The facts are that our stevedoring charges have declined'.
(4) The Australian Peak Shippers Association (APSA) has on a number of occasions claimed that freight rates have not been reduced as a result of the Governments recent waterfront program.

Shippers have received benefits from the Government waterfront reform program through the marked improvement in stevedoring performance within Australia's key container ports. The June 2000 issue of the Bureau of Transport Economics publication Waterline reported that the five-port average crane rate reached a record 20.4 containers per hour for the March quarter 2000. This compared with 19.1 containers per hour for the December quarter 1999. The rates at which the stevedores work ships also reached new records due to better utilisation of quay cranes. The five-port net ship rate was 31.8 containers per hour for the March quarter 2000, well above the pre-Patrick dispute figure of 24.3 containers per hour.
Berth availability also reached a new high point of 94 per cent, which is just short of the Government's reliability benchmark of 97 per cent.
(5) Yes.
(6) Refer to answer in question (4) above.
(7) Yes. I met Lord Sterling while in London earlier this year. Our discussion covered a range of issues relating to P&O Ports activities in Australia including the recent waterfront reform process.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 15 August 2000:

quote.para: (1) What is the current share of national road funding received by Victoria.
(2) Has Victoria's share changed over recent years; if so, by what sums has it changed.
(3) How long does the existing agreement for the division of national road funding last.
(4) What is the process by which roads are declared Roads of National Importance.
(5) On how many occasions during the period 1993-1999 did the Victorian Government seek to secure with the Federal Government an agreement over any Roads of National Importance.
(6) What was the first occasion in which the Victorian Government requested the Federal Government to agree to declaring the Scoresby Freeway a Road of National Importance.
(7) Has the Federal Government refused to fund the Scoresby Freeway project.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) Victoria's current National Highway and Roads of National Importance allocation totals $95.13m from a total national allocation of $816.84m.

(2) Victoria's funding share, as with all States and Territories, changes on an annual basis. For example, in 1998/99 Victoria's share of National Highway and Roads of National Importance was $107.4m from a total national allocation of $874.5m. In 1999/2000 Victoria's share was $84.7m from a total national allocation of $815.4m. Victoria's allocations for the years 2001/02 and 2002/3 are forecasted to increase to $220.8m and $205.9m respectively, depending on the ability of the Victorian Government to bring proposals to the point where tenders can be called.

(3) Road funding is based on competing priorities on a National basis and not on a predetermined States share agreement. Projects are assessed on their merits and focussed on those areas of the network where the largest net benefit can be achieved.

(4) Roads of National Importance can be nominated by State Governments or by specific interest groups. The broad criteria when designating Roads of National Importance is that the project is not on the National Highway system and that it will return significant economic benefit to the nation.
(5) The Roads of National Importance program started in 1996. The Victorian Government has sought funding for Roads of National Importance annually as part of their general road funding submission.
(6) Since the early 1990s the Victorian Government has sought to secure funding for the Scoresby Freeway. Under the Roads of National Importance program. Victoria has sought declaration since 1996.

(7) Development of the Scoresby Corridor is the responsibility of the Victorian Government. The Federal Government, for its part, is prepared to discuss with Victoria how best construction of the Scoresby Corridor might be funded. The release of the Partnerships Victoriapaper by Victoria provides an ideal policy platform from which private sector development of Scoresby could be pursued.

subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 1818)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 16 August 2000:

quote.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 510 (Hansard, 12 May 1999, page 5318) concerning rescue operations during the Sydney to Hobart Yacht Race, what was the final cost to his Department for employing civil search and rescue resources in assisting rescue operations.
(2) Was any of the cost recoverable from the-organisers of the race, the Cruising Yacht Club of Australia; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Australian Maritime Safety Authority (AMSA) arranged and paid for the use of civil resources for search and rescue operations for the Sydney-Hobart Yacht Race during the period 27-29 December 1998. The total cost to AMSA was $697,101.40.
(2) None of the costs were recovered.

Search and rescue services are provided by AMSA in pursuance of the AMSA Act and in accordance with relevant maritime and aviation international conventions. The .conventions are based on the humanitarian principle of rendering assistance to those in distress without regard to their origins. Successive Australian Governments have accepted that funding for search and rescue services is provided as a community service obligation. This accords with the worldwide practice of signatories to the conventions.

talk.start.para: —The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) (a) and (b) Yes.

(2) Generally, yes. Early release of preserved benefits is possible, subject to the governing rules of the fund, if the benefits are taken in the form of a lifetime non-commutable pension or annuity, are restricted non-preserved benefits, or on compassionate grounds in certain limited circumstances.

The purpose of the superannuation preservation rules is to ensure that superannuation savings that have benefited from Australian tax concessions are used to provide income in retirement and not for other purposes.
