talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 7 September 2000:

quote.para: (1) Are there Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) regulations governing the regularity of checking and clearing debris and objects from runways at Australia's capital city and major regional airports, if so (a) how often are checks required, (b) does CASA conduct audits to ensure airport compliance with CASA runway inspection regulations, (c) how many audits have been conducted since 1995, and at which airports have they been conducted and (d) have there been any prosecutions or show cause notices issued to airport operators with respect to the runway inspection regulations since 1995.
(2) Is the airport owner or operator responsible for ensuring the checks occur.
(3) Do airport operators record the frequency of runway checks.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: The Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) has advised the following:

(1) Yes. Civil Aviation Regulation (CAR) 89H requires the operator of a licensed aerodrome to have an aerodrome manual, and CAR 89I states that the information which must be included in the aerodrome manual is shown in Schedule 10 of the CARs. All capital city aerodromes are licensed. All regional aerodromes which are used by regular public transport (RPT) aircraft with a seating capacity exceeding 30 passengers must also be licensed and all aerodromes may apply to be licensed regardless of the presence or size of RPT operations.

Schedule 10 requires the operator of a licensed aerodrome to include, in the aerodrome manual, information about the aerodrome as well as the arrangements that are in place to ensure that safety is maintained. These include details of the arrangements for carrying out inspections of the movement area (including runways), arrangements for keeping records of the inspections, frequency of the inspections, an inspection checklist, arrangements for reporting and correcting any unsafe conditions and the names and roles of the aerodrome staff who are responsible.

(a) Chapter 9 of the CASA publication 'Rules and Practices for Aerodromes' contains details of aerodrome inspection requirements, including the frequency of inspections. At aerodromes with 24 hour Air Traffic Control (ATC), inspections are required each day as soon as practicable after first light, after significant weather phenomena such as strong winds or heavy rain, and when requested by ATC. At other aerodromes, inspections are required each day before the first daylight public transport service movement, after significant weather phenomena such as strong winds or heavy rain, and when requested by Airservices Australia or CASA. Aerodrome operators may exceed these minimum requirements and CASA can direct an aerodrome operator to alter the procedures using CAR 89M if required to ensure the safety of aircraft.

(b) Yes. CASA employs 12 Aerodrome Inspection staff who conduct audits of all licensed aerodromes in accordance with the Aviation Safety Surveillance Program (ASSP). The audits include all aspects of the procedures in the aerodrome manual, including aerodrome inspections.

(c) There are approximately 260 licensed aerodromes in Australia, which are all audited on a regular basis in accordance with the ASSP. The program specifies an audit each 12 months for aerodromes which are used by RPT aircraft with more than 9 passenger seats and each 24 months for all other licensed aerodromes and for unlicensed aerodromes which are used for RPT operations.
(d) No. There have been no prosecutions or Show Cause Notices issued to aerodrome operators in relation to runway inspections since 1995.

(2) Yes. The aerodrome operator is responsible for ensuring that the checks occur. CAR 89M states that the aerodrome operator must operate and maintain the aerodrome in accordance with the procedures set out in the aerodrome manual.
(3) Yes. The aerodrome manual must include details of the frequency of checks, the checklist used and a logbook or other system for recording inspections.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 3 October 2000:

quote.para: (1) What increase in funding for microcredit has been included in the 2000-2001 aid budget.
(2) Is the additional funding supporting lending to the poorest people.
(3) Is the funding being used to enable non-government organisations to distribute assistance to individual microcredit programs.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The Australian Government remains committed to doubling microfinance expenditure through the aid program within the life of the current Parliament, consistent with ensuring a high quality portfolio of activities. In support of this commitment I announced in the 1999-2000 Commonwealth budget, a three-year $3 million fund to act as a catalyst for further assistance to the microfinance sector in partnership with developing countries in our region.

There has been no specific budget allocation for microfinance apart from this seed fund. This reflects the fact that the Government's microfinance commitment will be met by increasing the role of microfinance in its regular programs, not by introducing a separate allocation specifically for microfinance. The role of the seed fund is to facilitate this process. It is only if we succeed in giving microfinance a more secure and prominent role in AusAID regular bilateral and NGO programs that a long-term enhancement of Australia's contribution to the development of microfinance will be assured. A lot of work has been done and will continue to be done, much of it independently of the seed fund, to consolidate and expand the role of microfinance in Australia's aid program

(2) AusAID's microfinance projects target those among the poor who are able to make effective use of credit. Consequently, there is a strong focus on women, given their disproportionate representation among the poor, their reliability as borrowers and their propensity to use the income generated by loans to improve the living standards of their families.

(3) AusAID's microfinance expenditure is channelled through a number of intermediaries including Australian commercial contractors and non-government organisations (NGOs), both in Australia and in developing countries. Some of the Australian Government's funding is being used to enable NGOs to distribute assistance to individual microcredit programs. For example, part of the microfinance seed fund was made available to Australian NGOs in 1999/2000 and 2000/01 to increase their microfinance capacity and that of their implementing partners.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, upon notice, on 3 October 2000:

quote.para: (1) What efforts are being made to implement new technologies that would serve to loosen the grip that oil companies have on the Australian motorist.
(2) Is the Government exploring the idea of alternative fuels to be used in new cars, such as the use of ethanol based E-85 in all government cars in Illinois, USA.

(3) Is the Government prepared to follow the lead of other nations such as the USA and implement an initiative which would promote clean fuel-burning and also serve to help sugar farmers who could sell their sugar cane to produce the ethanol needed for E-85.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Industry, Science and Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: (1) The Government is providing significant support for the development of alternative fuels.

Ethanol, liquefied petroleum gas (LPG), and compressed natural gas (CNG) have been included in legislation as alternative fuels which are excise exempt. The excise exemption represents a cost to revenue of some $700 million each year. It provides a 38 cent per litre cost advantage compared to petrol and diesel.
The Government, through the Australian Greenhouse Office has an integrated strategy to encourage the use of cleaner alternative fuels through three programs:

answer.para: · The Alternative Fuels Conversion Program
· The CNG (Compressed Natural Gas) Infrastructure Program
· The Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme

quote.para: The Alternative Fuels Conversion Program (AFCP) is a four year, $75 million initiative which was commenced in January 2000. The Program applies to certain heavy commercial vehicles and provides funds of up to 50 per cent of either:

answer.para: · the difference between the purchase price of new CNG/LPG fuelled vehicles over their conventionally fuelled equivalents;
· the cost of converting conventionally fuelled vehicles to operate on CNG/LPG; or
· the cost of upgrading the fuel systems of vehicles already operating on CNG/LPG where improvements in greenhouse and other emissions can be demonstrated.

quote.para: The CNG Infrastructure Program (CNGIP) is a $7.6 million program designed to facilitate the establishment of a national network of CNG refuelling stations.

The Diesel and Alternative Fuels Grants Scheme (DAFGS) commenced in July 2000 and will maintain existing price relativities between diesel and a range of alternative fuels by allowing transport operators that are eligible for the diesel fuel grant to also be eligible for alternative fuel grants.
(2) Yes. The Government is actively exploring the use of alternative fuels such as ethanol.

In addition to the beneficial excise treatment of certain alternative fuels, on 20 June this year the Renewable Energy Action Agenda New Era - New Energy was launched. Under this Action Agenda the Australian Greenhouse Office has been tasked with managing the process of identifying key opportunities for the sustainable development and use of renewable transport fuels.
A Renewable Transport Fuels (RTF) Working Group has been established and had its first meeting on 5 September 2000.
At current levels of production of ethanol, there is insufficient supply to enable its use by all government vehicles. As a fuel its main use is as a blend stock in the production of petrol.

(3) Yes, the Government has a program to promote cleaner fuels. Environment Australia (in conjunction with the Department of Industry, Science and Resources and the Department of Transport and Regional Services other agencies and the refining and automotive industries) is currently developing new cleaner fuel specifications.
An important aim for the specifications is to reduce exhaust emissions. Currently, specifications for the principal transport fuels, petrol, diesel and LPG, are being developed.
The Government is aware of the potential benefits to the environment and to sugar cane farmers of a competitive, robust and ecologically sustainable fuel ethanol industry.

On 25 September 2000 the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, the Hon Warren Truss MP, announced the Government will fund a study, coordinated by ABARE, of the commercial viability of increasing production of ethanol by the Australian sugar industry.
The Government believes it is more appropriate for the industry to make commercial decisions about the use of ethanol, rather than for the Government to impose its use through legislation.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 12 October 2000:

quote.para: (1) Did the Government appoint a Steering Committee to oversee the development of its new SES-based model for the recurrent funding of non-government schools.
(2) Did three of the eight members of the Committee represent the Catholic Education Commission; if so, what are the details.
(3) Given the decision of the Catholic Education Commission not to participate in the SES system, why were three of its representatives invited onto the Steering Committee.

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr Kemp
talker.role: Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: (1) The SES Simulation Project conducted in 1998 was managed by my Department with the guidance of a Steering Committee representative of non-government schools.

(2) Membership of the Steering Committee included Mrs Therese Temby, National Catholic Education Commission; Mr Chris Duncan, NSW Catholic Education Commission; and Mr Frank Pegan, Victorian Catholic Education Office.

(3) The purpose of the SES Simulation Project was to explore the feasibility and validity of an SES approach to funding non-government schools. Although participation in the Project was purely voluntary, every Catholic system (and almost 100 per cent of Catholic systemic schools) participated in the Project. The decision to essentially preserve category 11 funding for Catholic systems (category 10 for the ACT system) was taken independently of the simulation exercise.
